editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ¬∂ The Contents of the foure Sections of the Art of Surueying.
The fir≈øt Section.
div.p: INtreateth of the Materialls of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, of the diuer≈øities of Earthes, Waters, Quarries, Mines, of the Cru≈øts and Inve≈øtures of Grounds with their peculiar Subduing, Manuring and Imploying, of fitting ≈øeuerall ≈øorts of Graine, Hearbes, Rootes, Plants with Plots of Conuenient Temper and appropriate Layer, of the Natures and kindes of Marle and Compo≈øt, of Ground-Plots, and Edifices.

div.head: The ≈øecond Section.
div.p: Sheweth the Situation, Re≈øidence and lying of Grounds ≈øuiting their ≈øeuerall Tempers, their Boundage and Neighbourage, with markeable ob≈øeruations ari≈øing from the ≈øame; the Mea≈øuring, Calculation, Plotting and Proiection of Lines, Figures, Bodies, Buildings, the Tricking of Plots and Maps with Colours, Characters, Charts, and other Complements.

div.p: Intimateth the Natures and Proprieties of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Tenures, Seruices, Titles, Rights, Fees, Immunities, Di≈øcents, and other Incidents.

div.head: The fourth Section.
div.p: Demon≈øtrateth how Lands and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions are valueable in re≈øpect of their ≈øeuerall I≈ø≈øues, Rents, Perqui≈øites, Priuiledges and other Accrewments, and Reuenueables, duely regarding their Repri≈øes.

The Mar≈øhalling and dige≈øting of the whole Suruey, contriuing of Field-Entries in Rough-books, Engro≈ø≈øing of the ExemplificatioÃÑs, the Surueying and abbreuiating of Deedes, Compo≈øing of Terrars, Rentals, Particulars, &c.

div.head: ‚ùßTo the Right Honourable and mo≈øt Noble Lord, WILLIAM Lord Compton, Baron of Compton, Ne≈øtors yeeres, with the felicitie of both Worldes.
div.p:
TO deriue my inducements (Right Honourable) of Dedicating the≈øe ≈øhallow De≈øeignes vnto a Mecaenas of ≈øuch Supereminence, from Pre≈øidents of worthy witts and particular Obligees to eminent Patrons, my Fortunes haue not ≈øo au≈øpiciou≈øly endeared me their happy Fauourite. But the Vniuer≈øall concurrence of good Hearts with hearty zeale (from the Verge of a va≈øte extent) in the Center of true affectionated prai≈øe of your worth, and prayers for your weale, hath ha≈øted & haled-on the whole Current of my affections to runne with the Generall Concur≈øe of vnfained welwillers, to congratulate your Lord≈øhips hopefull and happie Con≈øolidations: For ≈øuch and ≈øo manifold are tho≈øe worthy Attributes of accompli≈øhed Amplitude and magnified Merits dimayning from the ≈øacred Source of true Nobility, that they haue euen winged my feruent De≈øires, (more animated with ≈øelf-approument of deuote ≈øinceritie then amazed with myrrors of Magnificence) to the con≈øecrating of the≈øe my pre≈øt De≈øeignemeÃÑts to your Honourable Patrocinie. But if ≈øuch Motiues bee incompetent to giue due Colour of excu≈øe to Intru≈øions ≈øo exorbitant, I be≈øeech
your Lord≈øhip giue me leaue to flee to the pro≈øtrate Plea of praying your gracious Indulgence for my rude Pre≈øume in daring from the remote Nadir of ob≈øcurity, to eleuate the flaggie Wing of ≈øo weake a Pineon towards the Zenith of Perfection, the mark and Pitch for Skie-towring Faulcons, who≈øe Quills imped with ≈øtrong Sarcells of the Grace of Greatnes, are inli≈øened and inhabled to tran≈øcende and climbe-aboue the mi≈øtie Vapours that cloude and Eclip≈øe all Flights which peirce not to the Welkin of the Worthies. For who ≈øees not that Heroes (Gods Vice-gerents) can dignifie euen the inglorious Groome, & giue ≈øuch Glo≈ø≈øe, and Tincture to home-made Statuaes, as ≈øhal attract the Eye of wonder to magnifie the potent Arti≈øts for refining & remoulding their (now) new creatures, as well as with the Touch-≈øtone of refined knowledge detrud & bani≈øh all De≈øeignes, disfurni≈øht of true & due ≈øelf-worth, from the Confines of high Repute? But lea≈øt in labouring, with invulgar Ingredients, to palate an ill ≈øea≈øoned Seruice, I ≈øhould by tedious and vnreli≈øhed Tearmes, impart a wor≈øe di≈øta≈øte, I will ≈øcrew-vp this Key with the pro≈øtrate ≈øacring of my ≈øelfe and my poore Endeauours at the Shrine of your gracious Clemencie. And ≈øo euer wi≈øhing vnto your Honour the happie fruition of vnconfined Felicity. I re≈øt, now and euer,

div.head: To the Beneuolent and iudicious READER.
div.p:
SHould I in≈øi≈øt vpon tedious Appologies for due approuement of the Faculty of Surueying impugned by the vulgar and ≈øhallow Di≈øputes of refractorie Oppo≈øites, which ab≈øurdly transferring their hard Imputations again≈øt it, from the faulty and defectiue Abu≈øe, to the iu≈øt and lawfull V≈øe of the ≈øame, doe mo≈øt iniuriou≈øly, and vniu≈øtly traduce and ≈øcandalize this vnblameable Arte & all her Agents, 'tis hazard but I ≈øhould heare of Mindaes Cynical Memento, if I incurred no harder a Cen≈øure. It is a World to ≈øee the ≈øotti≈øh pre≈ø≈øures vrged again≈øt the admea≈øuring of land, yet the V≈øe of Ponderous and Concaue Mea≈øures (both Dry and Liquid) are no le≈ø≈øe commendable than Common in venting of Wares and Merchandize, and what greater iniquity in the v≈øing admea≈øurements in Grounds than in Graine? Cloath and Stuffes were retailed by the yard, when a ≈øumptuous Potentate might be ho≈øed for 3 ≈øhillings, which now will ≈øcarce ho≈øe a frugall Pea≈øant. Bilanx est arbiter aequus; the Hand may faile in certaintie of Poize, and the Eye in Randon ≈øans Rule, but the Beame and Chaine balke no Truthes, nor blaunch Vn-truthes; the Empirick or the Methodi≈øt, which is the better Phi≈øician? Take away Number, Weight, Mea≈øure, you exile Iu≈øtice, and reduce and haile-vp from Hell the olde and odious Chaos of Confu≈øion. Priuate Intelligencers, intimating (by their roaued Aymes at Quantities and Qualities) vnder-hand and ≈øini≈øter informations, abu≈øe the Le≈ø≈øor & wrong the Le≈ø≈øee, where the iu≈øt and iudicious Feudigrapher (who aymes at competent Improuements ≈øans pre≈ø≈øure of the Feudatarie, or oppre≈ø≈øure of the Fermor) duly and di≈øcreetly ob≈øeruing all particulars incident to the Plot, certifies a true Relation, by the Leuel-draught of who≈øe impartiall Parallels, may be produced that Meane in Rating of E≈øtimates, which the due Port of men of Place and Eminence (no way ≈øupportable (Rebus ≈øic ≈øtantibus) with Reuenewes of former Ages) doth mo≈øt iu≈øtly challenge. What ≈øhould I ≈øpeake of ≈øcanted E≈øtimates of Acres exacted from ouer-awed Tenants, or rated
by po≈øitiue Will? of the Ouertures of ≈øcandall rai≈øed again≈øt Surueyors by the Owners concealing of failing Contents, or vouching of Validities and Extents aboue the Feudigraphia impo≈øtur√† fit P≈øeudographia. Record? of letting by Port-≈øaile aduanced by prepared out-bidding Competitors? of parcelling forth engro≈ø≈øed lands to Vnder-tenants at intollerable Termes? of Riot, Pride, Plenty of People & Coyne (though confined to a few Cofers) with high-enhaunced Rates of all Commodities? who is ≈øo Owle-eyed that ≈øees not, that the extending of Rents doth nece≈ø≈øarily dimaine from the≈øe and the like cau≈øes? Yet Tenancies (I cannot gaine-≈øay) are too oft tendered to too-Racking Valuations, the Reciprocall Regard (in ≈øome) is Choy≈øe to take by Racke, or leaue a Packe, and it is ≈øo ordinary with too many Land-lords (like ab≈øolute Lords and Allodi≈øts of their Lands (within the Verge at lea≈øt) √° ≈øuperis ad inferos) Fundum hastae ≈øubijcere, the frequencie of the practize growes familiar. And for Feudataries, who ≈øees not how much they faile of true agnizing their due dependance vpon Me≈øne Lords,Dwarenus. ≈øith Feudum (comprehending Fealty (at lea≈øt) which obliges Per ≈øacramentuÃÑ ≈øub pena foris facturae Feodi) is Res Clientelaris, & neuer deuolues to the Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øans original Burthens impo≈øed by him which had Nouel Fee, how≈øoeuer they now ≈ølight their Lords and amoundre their Obligence. Sed haec parerga; and to Rectifie ≈øuch irregularities, the Field requires a better Champion, in the meane time let euery one for his owne particular propo≈øe vnto him≈øelfe the entertainment of a good con≈øcience. For this Tractate, I am not ≈øo arrogant to magnifie, nor ≈øo vnnatural to vilifie my own i≈ø≈øue, though I could retriue Centuries of Defects, but leaue it to thy fauourable Cen≈øure, crauing (withall) thy courteous tolleration of my new-coyning of ≈øome Words, with the Reuiuing of the ob≈øolete and Endenizing of Forraine, ≈øith without ≈øuch priuiledge, an indige≈øted Chaos of Principles and Conclu≈øions cannot (ex nouo & ex facili) be conci≈øely contriued into a Methodicall Arte. For any vaine-glorious Geodetor, which makes ba≈øe Detraction the Trumpet to rumour, and embla≈øon his ≈øelfe-boa≈øted perfections, ≈øo with facility to purcha≈øe (or rather fore-≈øtall) the Palme of Repute,
Ore & Dente petat, & na≈øo ≈øuspen≈øo huiu≈ømodi effundat Scommata:
Quam lepid√® lexeis compostae vt te≈ø≈øerulae, omnes
Arte pauimento at
que Emblemate vermiculato?
What curious-quaint Emelli≈øhments diffu≈øe?
Mu≈øaick-Mazes-Marquetrizing Mu≈øe?

Su≈ø
que de
que fero; who can be ≈øecured from ba≈øe carping Blatancie? But wherevnto tendes this preci≈øe particularizing of Plots, Layers, Pregnances, Productions, &c. when an Arte-le≈ø≈øe Agent can (by famed Name, and ab≈øolute power to di≈øpo≈øe) with the bare vouch of the generall goodne≈ø≈øe of the Ground (≈øans ground of Rea≈øon or Po≈ø≈øibility) haile on the poore Pe≈øant to Farme and Fine according to the braue boa≈øt of his roauing E≈øteemes & ab≈øurd O≈øtentations, which he daignes not (nor dare they vrge) by any rationall in≈øtances to make probable? I ayme not at the Racke nor the Slack, the qualified Meane is the Maine of my Marke; and to extunde and beat-out this true Proportion, I ob≈øerue the Circum≈øtances proiected: let peremptorie Agents balke in≈øtance, barre Reply, and Racke ≈øans Rule and Rea≈øon, it behoues an hone≈øt and faithfull Feudigrapher, by infallible Principles & warrantable Demon≈øtrations, to approue him≈øelfe, an intelligent and diligent-Improuer, not a ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe and arrogant Impo≈øtor; and what warrant more current than Knowledge founded vpon the indu≈øtrious ≈øearch and ≈øerious ob≈øeruations intimated (or rather glaunced at) in this Epitome? But lea≈øt too large Gates ≈øhould promi≈øe a faire Plat-forme of a ≈øpatious Towne, hauing thus borrowed leaue to wade into the ≈øhallow Foordes of the Faculty, I will leaue the Profundities to be ≈øounded with a Plumbe-line of more Poize and Fadomes.

div.head: The Author to his Feudigraphia.
div.l: WHen thus I had (by peice-meale paines) compilde
Of diuers Elements thy ≈ølender Bulkes,
I deem'de to haue (too ominou≈øly) ≈øtylde
Thy Name ≈øo neere the Pheud of Border-Hulkes,
That thy abortiue Limbes I rather cho≈øe
In clo≈øe concealement from this captious Age
To ≈ømoother ay, than ra≈øhly thus t'expo≈øe
To Pheudi≈øts Theonine thy Pu≈øilage;
But a great Monarch hath tho≈øe dire Combines
Hatcht in the Heart by Sauage Enion,
Calm'de with a Fame that happily Confines
All Oppo≈øites, to ≈øacred Vnion:
So wert thou Patroniz'de by Cel≈øitude,
The Cryticke-Coale ≈øhould not thy Browes ybrand
For Dis-analogies ≈øtrange, ≈øtrained, rude,
Nor Deviations curious-ill-≈øcande;
Gaine then, O gaine (in Lieu of ≈øelfe demerit)
By heart-free Tender with true zeale repleate,
His grac'de A≈øpect, who truely doth inherit.
A ≈øplendid Fame for worthynes Compleate,
To daigne the Patronage I (humble) craue
Of Worthy Comptons Noble Family,
Who≈øe iu≈øtly-honourd Names Shield from Depraue,
Couch rabid Blatants, ≈øilence Surquedry:
Then Carping Momus wilbe euer-mute,
And rather Bur≈øt with Spleene, than vent his Gall,
The Mainger-Curre nil bawle (how-euer brute)
But crouching fawne, or leering voide the Stall;
Such Grace dimaines from ≈øacred Eminence
Ay to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe in≈øulting In≈øolence.

div.head: THE SYNOPSIS OR EPITOME OF SVRVEY METHODIZED.
SECTION .I.

argument.p: Of the Materials of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, the ≈øeuerall kinds of Earths, Waters, Stones, Minerals: the Cru≈øts and increa≈øe of Grounds, the peculiar ordering, mastering, manuring and imploying of ≈øeuerall Soyles, the due be≈øtowing of Graine, Herbs, Plants; with the diuer≈øitie of Ground-plots and Edifices.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p: SVruey in generall is an Art wherby the view and trutinate intimation of a ≈øubiect, from Center to Circumference is rectified.
The Suruey of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions (the ≈øubiect of this Treati≈øe) is the Arte by which their Graphicall De≈øcription is particularized.
This Suruey is Symbolized and di≈øtingui≈øhed into Actiue and Pa≈ø≈øiue.
Actiue.The Actiue may be referred to the Feudigrapher, and con≈øi≈øts in Operation and E≈øtimation.
The Operation is Mathematicall and Mechanicall.
Mathematicall.Mathematicall Operation is a part of Suruey by which the dimen≈øions of the Plots propounded are performed.
Mechanical.Mechanicall Operation is the Manuall acting and proiecting of the workes.
The E≈øtimation of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions is Materiall & Legall.
Materiall.The Materiall part is conuer≈øant in E≈øtimating the valuations incident to the ≈øubiect, by relation to the Materials, and Elementarie parts of the Plot.

Legall.The Legall part pre≈øcribes Methodicall & Iuridiciall confines to the whole cour≈øe of Suruey: and comprehends the Symboliographie or Clarke-≈øhip, and penning of the Suruey with the Rectifying of Euidences and Records.
The ≈øeuerall functions of the≈øe partes are diffu≈øed thorough the whole Proce≈ø≈øe en≈øuing.
And ≈øo much for the Actiue part.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: Pa≈ø≈øiue.The Pa≈ø≈øiue part of Suruey, hath reference to Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, as they con≈øi≈øt of parts E≈ø≈øentiall and Accidentall.
E≈ø≈øentiall.The E≈ø≈øentiall partes comprehend the matter and forme coincident to Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions.
Matter.The Matter compri≈øes the Elementarie compo≈øition and con≈øtitution of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: and in di≈øcu≈ø≈øure thereof, the Materiall parte is mo≈øt conuer≈øant.

The Matter is either Naturall, who≈øe ≈øtate hath admitted of no ≈øub≈øtantiall alteration, other then the hand
of Nature hath impre≈ø≈øed therein: or Artificiall, tran≈øformed and chaunged from the Natiue and Originall Habite by humane indu≈øtrie.
Naturall matter may bee diuided into Appropriate and Communicate.Naturall.
Appropriate is that which is peculiar and proper to ≈øome certaine per≈øon, place, or other particular limitation; and hath reference here to Earth and Water.
In the Earth the Qualitie and Compo≈øure thereof are to be con≈øidered.Earth.
In the fir≈øt the Species and Habitude require to bee iudiciou≈øly ob≈øerued.
The Species of the Earth is either Vulgar or Pretious.Species.
The Vulgar is either Simple, as Clay, Moulde,Vulgar. Moore, Grauell, Sande: Or Commixt; as Creachie, Claulkie, Clayie, Sandie Earth.

Pretious Earth is that which con≈øi≈øts of a middle Nature twixt Stones and Mettals;Pretious. and all ≈øorts thereof are Friable and conuertible to Powder: And the≈øe are either Liquable or Not-Meltable.Liquable.
The fir≈øt are Iuices Concrete; as Salt, Alume, Bitumen, Vitrioll.
Salt (Naturall) is found either in the Earth or Water. Of the fir≈øt kind is Salt Armoniake, Sal-gem,Salt. Sal-niter, and Indian Salt.
The other ≈øort is digged vp in Fountaines, Riuers, Wa≈øhes, Salt-Meeres, Sea-≈øhoares.
Alume is either white or blacke,Alume. The fir≈øt (and be≈øt) is either Liquid or Compact.
Liquid Alume is the ≈øoft, fat and limpid Roch (or Red) Alume.
The Compact is ether Sugar like, or Shiuering.
The blacke is a kinde of Alume wherewith gold is purged and purified.

Bitumen is either hard, as A≈øphaltus, Pi≈ø≈øa≈øphaltus,Bitumen.
Ro≈øin; Or Liquid, as Naphta, Petroleum, Amber, Vitriol, Coppras.

Not-meltable.The Pretious Earths, which are not Meltable, nor indurated into Stones nor Mettals, are Stibium, Azure, Auripigmentum or Ar≈øenicke, Sandaracha, Calx, Play≈øter, Chaulke, Coale, Canole, Marle, Oker, Terra-≈øigillata, or Lemnia, Armenia, Germanica, &c. Tuckers or Fullers Earth, Argilla or clay for Pots, Gallie and Thacke Tiles, Bricke, Water and Tabacco Pipes, Pur≈ølaine.
And thus much for the Species.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: Habitude.THe Habitude of the Earth dependes vpon the inherent di≈øpo≈øition and temperature of the ≈øame in Heate, Colde, Moi≈øture and Drine≈ø≈øe. For although in regarde of the Colde and Drie ≈øub≈øtance and Nature, whereof the Earth generally con≈øi≈øts, it may be ≈øaide to be of one temperature; yet vppon occa≈øion of the diuer≈øitie of Situations, Affinitie, Intercour≈øe and participation it hath with things of repugnant qualitie, it purcha≈øeth and acquireth contrarie qualities.

And therefore it would be al≈øo perue≈øtigated, whether it be light,, loo≈øe, ≈øofte, fatt, oylie, ≈ølipperie, mouldring, cleauing, tough, ≈øtiffe, moorie, leane, barren, fertile, water-≈øwallowed, ≈øoale bound, con≈øtipated, or what other due or vndue poize nad proportion of temper predominates.
Compo≈øure.The Compo≈øure of the Earth compri≈øes the Ba≈øe and vpper Cru≈øt of the ≈øame.

Ba≈øe. Pregnance.The Ba≈øe of the Earth offers due ob≈øeruation to perue≈øtigate the Pregnance wherewith the Earth is imbowelled, whether it bee Prime; as in the precedent
Species; or Concrete, as in Quarries and Mines.

In the fir≈øt di≈øcouer, what Ragge, Free≈øtone,Quarries. Mil≈øtone, Grind-≈øtone, Syth-≈øtone, Emeril-≈øtones, Sanguinin-≈øtones, Hones, Tutch, Ieate, Slude, Slate: What Marbles, as Alabla≈øters, Ophites, Porphyris, &c. Al≈øo what Gemmes, as harde Adamants, viz. the Cenchros, Macedonicke, Cypricke, Siderite: the flammid Carbuncle, purple Amethi≈øt, greene Emeraulde, and Opall Paderas, with their Trineuned lu≈øter: the vyolet Hyacinth, Skie-coloured Saphire, Lu≈øtrie Diamonde, ≈øhining Topaz, ≈øtarrie Calchedonie, ≈øparkling Rubie, golden Chry≈øolite, ≈øplendid A≈øterite, various Achate, horny Corneol, greene Ia≈øper, pellucid Onyx, cerule Tarqueis, candid Cry≈øtall, harde Blood-≈øtone, attracting Loade-≈øtone, white yellow and Falerne Agate.

For the ≈øecond note, what Mettals or Minerals,Mines. are therein generated? whether Pure as Golde, Siluer; or impure as Leade, Tinne, Bra≈ø≈øe, Iron, Steele, Lattin, Copper, Coperas, Quick≈øiluer, Stibium, Antimonie, Chry≈øocolla or Boras, Minium or Vermilon naturall, Sandaracha, Verdigreece, Salt, Allome, Brim≈øtone.
Al≈øo Coale, Canole, Colours among≈øt the Minerall Oare of Gold and Siluer, as Sil, Azure.

The vpper Cru≈øt is the Soile or Seale of the Earth through which the irradiation of the Sun penetrating,Cru≈øt. corroborates & cheeres vp the Natiue heate with temperate calefaction, which together with the infu≈øion of moderate ≈øhowers and moi≈øtures, ≈øoaked from ≈øoilings enlifens the radicall humour, and doth ≈øo foment and ferment the whole Ma≈ø≈øe of Moulde, that Dame Ve≈øta is inuited and extimulated to inue≈øt her ≈øelfe in her riche≈øt Roabes of painted brauerie, and to produce and power foorth her Cornu-copia of ≈øelected plenties.

The Cra≈ø≈øitude.The Cra≈ø≈øitude of the Soale, is diuer≈øified in ≈øeuerall Plots, and particular Modulets, as from 3. foote, to ¬Ω foote more or le≈ø≈øe, and is di≈øtingui≈øhable from the Ba≈øe by compacture, by qualitie, by colour, by extention of the roots and fibers of gra≈ø≈øe, herbes, plants. And vpon this Cra≈ø≈øitude of the Cru≈øt, together with the Qualitie and Habitude of the ≈øame, doth the production principally depend (although the e≈øtate of the Ba≈øe (by rea≈øon of the imparture of the innate facultie) be not vtterly excluded all importance of fertilitie) and offers due ob≈øeruation, what Trees, Plants, Shrubs, Graine, Gra≈ø≈øe, Herbes, Weeds, Mo≈ø≈øe, and other Vegitables are in each Plot voluntarily or plentifully produced.
Inue≈øture.And hence dimaines the Inue≈øture of the earth, which giues con≈øideration of the Grouth & Repletion of productions, both Vegetant and Animall.

GrouthIn Grouth, the thriuage, verdure, fruitage, prematurance &c. of particular Vegetables are regardable; as the boaling, ≈øpreading, arming, timbring & tapering of trees, braunching and bearing of Plants, Bu≈øhing of Shrubs, prolation and ≈øeedage of roots and herbs, depth and colour of gra≈ø≈øe, &c. For thereby (≈øans further ≈øearch) the Species and Habitude of the ground, wherein they grow, are ingeniou≈øly intimated.

Soils known by their productions.For if they pro≈øper and thriue in burgening, ≈øappines, flowers, fruit and the like, according to their ≈øeuerall kinds, in extraordinarie good proportion, it implies that either the ground is very fertile in generall, or that they are implanted in Plots Sympathizing with their Natures.

As the high timbring Oake dilating mightie armes in large extent, denotates a rich and battle ≈øoile; where on the contrarie, the knurly, crooked and crabbed harde ≈øparing ≈øtarueling, bewraies his barren and hungrie bedde.

The large and loo≈øe grained timber of the red Oake
and fru≈ø≈øhie A≈øh ≈øhowes a light, moi≈øt, rich & d√©epe ≈øoile: the like doth the largene≈ø≈øe and wateri≈øhne≈ø≈øe of rootes and fruit.
But the firme and ≈øolid graine of the white Oake and tough A≈øh, ≈øignifies a more fa≈øt and clo≈øe ground. ¬Ω
High grounds produce wood of a more beautifull-featherd and better graine, than the low, except in Apple trees and Peare tr√©es.
Re≈øt-harrowes growing rancke and rooting farre abroad, intimate a fat, fruitfull, and long la≈øting ≈øoile.

The lowe ≈øtubbed Heath, argues a barren grauellie cold ground, the rancke and high ≈øhowes it to be a more warme and tillable; and commonly the white flowred Heath hath better layer, than the purple.

Diuels-bit, Eye-bright and yarrow by plentie in repletion, and mean in proportion, point foorth a Sandy earth, of moderate heat and moi≈øture, and a ≈øweet ≈øhallow and wel-≈øwoorded Cru≈øt: and thus are the≈øe herbes frequent in the Iri≈øh Soile.
Groun≈øwell, Thi≈øtles, Nettles, and other w√©edes by their rankene≈ø≈øe ≈øhow a rich tilth.
Blacki≈øh, mi≈øliking and vnkinde herbes ≈øhow a leane hungrie and bitter, or ≈øowre ground.
Burnt & ≈øcorched herbes, and har≈øh, reddi≈øh, blewi≈øh ≈øpirie and prie-gra≈ø≈øe bewray a cold, vnkind, rough, ≈øtarued and baked, or ≈øoaked ≈øoile.

Ba≈øe herbes, and rough ≈øandy ≈øtone, denotate a leane greety ≈øandie or grauelly ground, according to the Poet:
Nam Ieiuna quidem cliuo≈øi glarea ruris
Vix humiles apibus ca≈øias rorem
que mini≈øtrat,
Et tophus ≈øcaber &c.
Iuniper demon≈øtrates a chalky, drie and meane ≈øeat.

The knagged Mo≈ø≈øe mattes and cloathes the barrenne≈øt Mountaines with horned ≈øhoots, but promi≈øes that the Minerals of Iron, Leade, Tinne and Coale, ≈øhall Counteruaile the infertiltie of Soile with the rich Balla≈øte
enwombing the intrals of his ≈øpacious Ba≈øe.
And thus much for the ob≈øeruations to bee collected from the grouth of Vegetables.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: Animalia.THe qualitie of the Soile is al≈øo not ob≈øcurely intimated by con≈øideration of the breedage of the Animals therein produced: for it is commonly ≈øeene that Cattle, Fowle, Fi≈øh, and other liuing Creatures doe differ and varie in colour, Bone, proportion and other peculiar attributes according to their places of Breede.

The large limbed Neate, Hor≈øe and Sheepe betoken that they had their breeding in fat and rich ≈øoiles. But the ≈ømall and ≈øound Sheepe, cleane limbed Hor≈øe and Bea≈øt of meane bigne≈ø≈øe bewraies a harde Country and ≈øhallow Cru≈øt.

In Ireland, where the ≈øoile is not d√©epely rancke, but moderately fertile, both in tillage and forrage, their Cattle and all other liuing Creatures (Men & Greyhounds onely excepted) are of a meane and middle ≈øtature and proportion, ≈øuitable to the ≈øoilage.
Yet the Sh√©epe of Cot≈øwolde (quamuis ≈øitus ≈øit & collinus & gracilis) are of great bone, large Necks and ≈øquare Bulkes.
But according to the Nature of the Countries, diuers Animals are famou≈øed for peculier parts: ≈øo Virgil ≈øaith.

div.p: So wee haue the Ripon Colt, Northerne Bilder, Scotch & Welch Nags, Iri≈øh Hobbie, Spani≈øh Iennet.
The Engli≈øh and Frizeland St√©edes, Barbarian-Cour≈øers, Cappadocian Hunters.

The Sicilian Hor≈øe is prai≈øed for ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe as are al≈øo the br√©ede of Libia and Siculia, the Moorian for valour and courage, the Dutch Mare is in reque≈øt for the Caroach, and The≈ø≈øalonian Mares for battell.

The Parthian Hor≈øe is famed for nimblene≈ø≈øe and dexteritie in running: The Median is exc√©eding faire and great: the Sardinian faire and nimble: the Mi≈ø≈øeean is goodly, ≈øhapie, ea≈øie and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øiue.

The Mar≈øh and Holland Oxe is preferred for draught, the Lanca≈øhire and Darby≈øhire for tallow, hide and horne, and the≈øe are ≈øhort legged, of ≈øquare bulke and black haire, the other are tall, and (for the mo≈øt part) party-coloured.

The Methol Rabbet is famed for fatne≈ø≈øe and fle≈øhine≈ø≈øe: the Cot≈øwould weather for large body, d√©epe, fine, white, and ≈øoft fl√©ece: Norffolke Mutton for ≈øw√©etne≈ø≈øe, but Lem≈øter Ore merits the preheminence (though it be ≈øhort) for a purely-fine, ≈øoft and cri≈øped Staple.
The Goates of Angori are hung with ≈øhag ground-d√©epe, but tho≈øe of Morroco haue their haire of ordinary length and refined ≈ømallnes.
Engli≈øh For bignes, ≈øtrength, and fiercene≈ø≈øe. Ma≈øtiffes, Ga≈øe Hounds (or Lurchers) and TuÃÑblers, are in ≈øpecial reque≈øt: ≈øo We≈øtphalian Bacon.

Ru≈ø≈øia br√©eds white Beares and blacke Foxes, and I≈øland white Partridges, Phe≈øants, Faulcons, and Hares. Pegu carries the Palme for Parrets, & Mu≈øke-Cats, and Ceiland (nigh Calicut) for Elephants.
The Vandall Trout is held in high e≈øt√©eme, and w√©e approoue Wytham and Ancam, this for Eeles, and that for Pikes, Engli≈øh Pikes, and Oy≈øters.
So the Barbarie and Pembroke≈øhire Faulcons, and Tercell-gentles, I≈øland Ierfalcon and Ierkin, Iri≈øh Merline, Goo≈øe-hawlke, and Cocke of the wood, Engli≈øh Hobbie, and Sparrow-hawlkes.

And in regard of ≈øuch diuer≈øities coincident to many creatures, by rea≈øon of their Countreys of br√©ede, it is remarkeable to ob≈øerue the ≈øeuerall particulars peculiar vnto them: as in Hor≈øes their ≈øtature, courage, cleanne≈ø≈øe of limbes, ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe and ≈øeruiceablene≈ø≈øe; in ≈øh√©ep their bulke, depth and puritie of Staple; in Neat their bone, hide, and haire, in Rabbets their furre and fatne≈ø≈øe: and the like of other things according to their kind.
And thus much of earth appropriate.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: WAter Appropriate is either Commorant, viz. confined within the plot.Waters. Or Current, not terminated within the limits thereof.

Comorant. Stagnant.The fir≈øt is either Stagnant, as ≈øtanding Pooles, Ponds, Lakes, Loughes, M√©eres: Or ≈øtillant, viz: Springing or bur≈øting forth of the bowels of the earth, as Wels, Fountaines, Bathes, &c.

Fluent. Current.The ≈øecond is either Fluent, as Rils, Brookes, Riuers, ≈øpringing, and appearing with their fir≈øt ≈øource within the bounds of the Plot:Influent. Or Influent, viz: dimayning from el≈øewhere, and flowing or pa≈ø≈øing by or through the precincts and confines of the Plot. And to this place may al≈øo bee referred all ≈øw√©eping or floating Waters, which flit and fl√©ete to and fro with wind-catches,Floating. ≈øuch as bee the Waters falling & de≈øcending from Vplandi≈øh countreys by land-floods ≈øurrounding Fens, and other Flats.

And both the≈øe ≈øorts of Current Waters, though they pa≈ø≈øe thorow, and beyond both the plot and Priuiledge of the ≈øame, yet ≈øo farre forth as they may be pre≈øcribed and intituled to the bounds or liberties thereof, they are thereunto appropriate. So much for Matter Appropriate: Communicate followes.

div.head: CHAP VI.
div.p: COmmunicate Matter is that which is participable to the Plot together with other Places,Matter coÃÑ municate. and may bee referred to Water Tran≈øient and to the Climate.

Waters Tran≈øient are Riuers, Brookes,Waters Tran≈øient. Flouds (whence ≈øo euer dimayning) which pa≈ø≈øing beyond the extention and priuiledge of the Plot are communicably imparted to it, and to ≈øome other.

The Climate may al≈øo not improperly bee admitted as Communicate,Climate. in regard it may be ≈øaid to bee the ≈øame (and in ≈øome ≈øort not immateriall, by rea≈øon of the in≈øeperabilitie thereof) ≈øans manife≈øt change, in a greater circuit then the limits of one Lord≈øhip, or an ordinarie Plot, doe v≈øually extend vnto, yet in the Suruey of whole Continents and va≈øt Countries the Climate is not excluded from Appropriates:Latitude. But how≈øoeuer you di≈øtingui≈øh, it is not impertinent perticularly to be penned downe, viz: in what degr√©e of longitude and latitude the Plot is ≈øituate, and al≈øo in what Ayre, as Pellucid, milde, ≈øubtill, cleare, ≈øw√©et, per≈øant, ≈øoone hot and colde, healthfull: Or gro≈ø≈øe, clo≈øe, foggie, ≈øharpe,Aire. fenny, vaporous, vnhole≈øome: in what proportion of heat, colde, moi≈øture, drine≈ø≈øe: what windes, ≈øtormes, gu≈øts, are mo≈øt remarkeable: what ordinarie effects and accidents, are v≈øually ob≈øerued to en≈øue, and ≈øucc√©ede vpon immoderate fals of wet, or long continuance of drowth: And what Di≈øea≈øes as Catarrhes, Feuers-Fluxes, &c. are mo≈øt frequent and common. And the like for Cattell.
And be≈øides the≈øe and the former ob≈øeruations & di≈øtinctions,Nature of Waters. there is a peculiar intimation to be made of the nature and goodne≈ø≈øe of Waters.
Clay-waters are ≈øw√©et, thick, fat, and potable, requiring the lea≈øt proportion of Malt for Brewing.
Waters which haue a ≈øtony and grittie Current, doe by ≈øtrayning thorough the ≈øame become cooler, pure, ≈øw√©et, hole≈øome, and light of di≈øge≈øture.
Springs dimayning from thicke ≈øand, and ≈ølender grauell, quickly gather mudde, and they are not durable, pibbles and gro≈ø≈øe grauell affoord good and plea≈øant waters, were they of continuance.
The Marle grauell, ≈øtonie ≈øand, and redde ≈øtones produce be≈øt Waters.
The red ≈øtones with Plinie carry chiefe preheminence for euerla≈øting Springs, and water, coole and ≈øimply the be≈øt.
But the particular notifying of the Natures of ordinarie Waters, may bee with facilitie effected by the exact knowledge of the peculiar attributes, and properties of good Water.

Cogni≈øance of good Water.The be≈øt Waters are tho≈øe that deriue their Sources, and Originals from Rockes, or ≈øtonie Fountaines irradiated with the Orient-Sunne, ≈øliding in channels of hard and compact grauell or ≈øand, repleat with redde ≈øtones, or blacke and burnt carbuncle ≈øtones, of limpid cl√©erene≈ø≈øe, light in poize and di≈øge≈øtion, quicke in conuer≈øion of heat and coldne≈ø≈øe, cooler in Summer then in Winter, ≈øans ta≈øte, ≈ømell, and colour, yet readily taking tinctures and qualities infu≈øed, leauing no di≈øcoloured ≈øpots by ≈øtanding ≈øimple in a cleane ve≈ø≈øell, nor excrements by decoction, by imparting neat and pure complexions, ≈øound brea≈øts, and cl√©ere voices to the natiue Inhabitants.

Aquae Calidae.Be≈øides the≈øe ordinary waters, there be Aquae Calidae, other waters indued with medicinable qualities acquired by vertue of ≈øome Minerall, from whence they dimaine: as Bathes, Wels, Fountaines, ≈øpringing from Mines of Nitre, Sulphure, Allome, Bitumen, &c.
There be al≈øo Waters both vpon the Coa≈øt and within the land (as at the Namptwich, &c,) of ≈øo bracki≈øh a Brynage, that they wil be conuerted to Salt by boyling.Brynage.

Other waters tho they be not conuertable in approued mea≈øure and goodnes to Salt, yet they haue vertue to augment and refine ≈øalt which is boyled in them: ≈øo the Z√©elanders boyle Spani≈øh ≈øalt in Sea-water, to the increa≈øe of 45. in the hundred, that of Portingale 35, and that of Brouage 25.
Some Fountaines creame with a liquid Bitumen, like to the lake A≈øphaltus, as at Pitchford in the Countie of Salop.
Now for Repletion,Repletion. it intimates howe and wherewith the Plot is fraught, ≈øtored and repleni≈øhed both with Vegetants, and Animals: viz.

For woods, how peruiable, how penetrable, how enterlaced, as Timber with Tin≈øell, Coppice, or vnderwood: what Tr√©es, Plants, Shrubs: what Fruitage, Ma≈øtage, Gummage: what Hawlkes, Fowle, Venery, &c. are therein found and produced.
For Pa≈øture, and Meadow; how and with what Herbage the Cru≈øt or Sword is matted, mantled and ≈øwarthed: what decrement by Mo≈ø≈øe, W√©edes, Water, Stones, &c.
So in Waters, the kinds, goodne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtore of Fi≈øh, and Fowle, both peculiar and common, would bee recorded.
And thus much may ≈øuffice for the Naturall Matter; It followeth to entreat of the Artificiall.

div.head: CAP. VII.
div.p: THe matter may al≈øo be ≈øaid to be Artificiall,Matter Artificiall. in re≈øpect of labour and indu≈øtrie conferred vpon or about the Subiect and Adiunct of the Plot.
The≈øe incidents to the Subiect are comprehended vnder Tillage, and ground Plots.
Tillage.Tillage generally taken may comprehend all maner of husbandings of grounds, but it is heere limited to Vertilage and Fertilage.
Vertilage.Vertilage con≈øi≈øts in Deluage and Fictilage.
Deluage.Deluage is applyed about preparing, and putrifying of the Earth by ≈øtirring, to≈ø≈øing and turning of the ≈øame, according to the Poet.

p.hi:
Et cui putre ≈øolum, nam
que hoc imitamur arando: viz. Vt arando ≈øolum ≈øit putre: Ne
que enim (inquit Columella) aliud e≈øt colere quam ≈øoluere & fermentare terram.

div.p: And this Deluage is di≈øtingui≈øhable into Caruage and Scaphage.

Caruage.Caruage comprehends all ≈øorts of plowing of Grounds, as well ordinarie, viz. for Graine, Hempe, Line, &c. As Extraordinarie, viz. for Woods, Woade, Dyers-w√©ede, Rapes, Cole, Saffron, Mill, Millet, Panick,Scaphiage. Amilcorne, Spelt-corn, Garences, Dewgra≈ø≈øe, Iobs-teares, Comin-≈ø√©ede, Anni≈øe-≈ø√©ede, Worme-≈ø√©ede, Cotton-≈ø√©ede, Canarie-≈ø√©ede, &c.

Scaphage is the digging, deluing, and preparing of the Soile with Spades or other handie-tooles for the ≈øowing, ≈øetting, planting, and propagating of S√©edes, Hearbs, Plants, Tr√©es, &c. and is mo≈øt conuer≈øant in Gardens, Hort-yards, Hop-yards, Vine-yards.

And here it is expedient to animaduert what choice, ≈øelected, and endenized Hearbes, Plants, Fruits and Phi≈øicall Simples be implanted & be≈øtowed, with their Growth, Repletion, Fruitage, Fecunditie, with Contriuage both of Plots and Plants.

Fictilage.Fictilage is the forming & tran≈øforming of ye Matter in form or ≈øub≈øtance; as in making of Tile (for thack, roofe, cre≈øt, gutter, pauing) Brick, Pots, Tabaccopipes, ToÃÑnel or Conduit-pipes, Gla≈ø≈øe, Pur≈ølane, and other Pla≈ømature. If therefore the Plot doe affoord any Earth or
Clay, which may be accommodated to ≈øuch purpo≈øes, it behooues to record the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
div.p: FErtilage con≈øi≈øts in the enriching of the Soyle,Fertilage. and the Rectifying of the Production. And in pur≈øuite of this practi≈øe, diligent con≈øideration mu≈øt be had of the variation of the Plot, from the due Habitude of a rich and battle ground; to the like and equall condition, whereof, it mu≈øt be endeuoured by appropriate meanes to reduce the ≈øame, or at lea≈øt to correct and qualifie the vndue Habitude in the eminente≈øt exorbitance.
And it ≈øhall not bee ami≈ø≈øe to particularize the Natures and qualities both of good and badde ≈øoyles, to the end their di≈øtinctions may be facilized.

The Nature and goodne≈ø≈øe of ground is diuers waies be-tout and manife≈øted; as by the mixture, temperature,The Nature of grounds how known. colour, compacture, touch, weight, ta≈øte, ≈ømell, &c. together with the voluntarie Production and Repletion of the Plot.

Such a diffu≈øed mixture of Clay and Sande,Mixture. moy≈øture and dryeth, heat and cold as confounds their di≈øtinctions of deriuing appellation, from the eminent predominance of any particular qualitie inherent in the ≈øoyle, carries a generall approouement of goodne≈ø≈øe.

Virgill infers the be≈øt layer for Tillage to be an Earth which is blacki≈øh and darke, not too compact,Blacke. of a d√©epe cru≈øt, viz. fat vnder the ≈øhare, though it goe a d√©ep pitch, well putrified and re≈øolued, &c.
Nigra fere & pre≈ø≈øo pinguis ≈øub vomere terra
Optima frumentis &c.

And Mancinellus ≈øaith, it mu≈øt bee neither moy≈øt nor drie, waxing black after the plow, ea≈øie to be tilled, and where Rooks runne fluttering after the ≈øhare at the verie
h√©eles of the holder, and that not of ranke, but moderate fruitfulne≈ø≈øe, with which the deprecation of the Poet, doth not vnfitly concurre, where he ≈øhewes that moi≈øt layers, are knowne by ranke and aboundant gra≈ø≈øe.

div.p: But notwith≈øtanding the preheminence giuen to the blacke and darke colour,Red. ≈øome are induced to preferre the red layer, and ≈øo much the rather for that Adam (who was immediatly created of Earth) importeth Earth of a redde or ruddy colour: And experience al≈øo giues in≈øtance of diuers ≈øuch ≈øoyles (though not ≈øo frequent to confirme euerie man in the ≈øame opinion) of wondrous worth and fertilitie, among≈øt which the Territories of the Towne of Armagh in Ireland, are famou≈øed for la≈øting and perpetuall battlenes, as hauing time out of minde, as appeares partly by their va≈øte dung-hils, pe≈øtering both yards and ≈øtr√©ets, without any kinde of manuring, y√©elded plentifull increa≈øe of gra≈ø≈øe and graine, how≈øoeuer the Natiues attribute this continuing richne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øoyle to the ≈øpeciall benediction of their Sainted Patron Saint Patricke.

div.p: Cato in two ≈øignificant Epithites (≈øed per tran≈øennam) comprehends the ≈øeuerall attributes,Pulla & Cario≈øa. both of a good and bad ≈øoyle, viz: Pulla and Cario≈øa.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
div.p: THe Nature and qualitie of Grounds thus layde downe,Enriching. and the pre≈øent ≈øtate and Habitude duely con≈øidered, the meanes befitting for the Enriching of the Soyle will be more euident.
The enriching of Grounds doth con≈øi≈øt in Clearing and Chearing.
The clearing of the Ground is conuer≈øant in disburthening the Soile from incumbrances and annoyances, as Water, Stones, W√©edes, &c.

Surroundings.Surrounded grounds may be won by Sewing them with competent Draines, Tonnels, Goats, Sluces, and ≈øuch like, if the Water-fall be ≈øufficient; otherwi≈øe ≈øome Enginarie aide mu≈øt bee a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to mount the water by Screwes, Pullies, Poizes, by cau≈øing Vacuums, or reinforcing of Spirits into narrow ≈øtraights and Cylinders.

And to retriue the difference twixt the line of Leuel, and the Circular or Water-leuel; to the Earths Semi-diameter (viz: 3436 4/11 Italian Miles) ≈øquared, add the ≈øquare of the di≈øtance propounded, from the ≈øquare roote of their Totall take 3436 4/11: the Remainder is the difference.

Bogges.Spungy and boggy grounds mu≈øt be intertraced (corre≈øponding to the Current or Di≈øcent) with Trenches of ≈øome eight√©ene inches breadth both at toppe and bottome, and where the toughne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øwarth or turffe wil permit ≈øome ≈øpare ≈øpaces, may be vnder mined; but to pre≈øerue all the ≈øweard, you may couch good coggles, al-along≈øt the Trenches a competent height, and the ≈øoddes vpon them, ≈øo the water will ≈øoake and draine thorow: And this practi≈øe is mo≈øt approouable and peculiar in mildring Clay, which otherwi≈øe by ≈øhooting and melting downe into open Trenches, would choake vp the water-pa≈ø≈øages.

For Vegetable impediments, as Bu≈øhes, Shrubs,Bu≈øhes. Broome. Bryers, Furres, Whynnes, Broome, &c. they being once rooted vp by dogging or grubbing, the Plot mu≈øt be well plyed with the Plow, and ≈øewen ≈øome Crops ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely after: to which earing if well-≈øoyling with good Marle, and Stall-dung be added, they will bee vtterly extingui≈øhed, though they be rooted in a barren, hot and drie ≈øoile, their proper element; but the cau≈øe being remooued (vt ≈øupra) the effects of producing the≈øe bad burthens mu≈øt n√©eds ≈øurcea≈øe by con≈øequence.

the wet before the Tr√©es or Bu≈øhes bee eradicated, for their roots do naturally attract ≈øo much moi≈øture for their nutriment, that all the ground adiacent will be eft-≈øoones choaked with a continuall cold wet.

Thi≈øtles.But the former w√©eds with Thi≈øtles, Hemlocks, and all ≈øappie w√©edes cut downe in Wood-≈øeare, and often mowne againe whil≈øt they are tender, their roots will putrifie and rotte ouer-burthened with affluent iuyce wanting due and woonted pa≈ø≈øage for growth: and the Thi≈øtle ≈øtalke, mu≈øt not be permitted to re≈øt gr√©ene n√©ere to the earth, for by the euaporation thereof, it will adder-like reuiue and roote againe.

Mo≈ø≈øe.Mo≈ø≈øe generally is de≈øtroyed with Doues and Hens-dung, and it putrifies being turned-in with the Plow: But Bu≈øhes, and Shrubs, mu≈øt bee al≈øo remooued, for by their oft-droppings of wette retained after ≈øhowers, mi≈øts and deawes, the ≈øwarth or turffe is ≈øo infrigidated and chilled, that being continued for or conuerted to meadowe, or grazing, it eft-≈øoones rea≈ø≈øumes his mo≈ø≈øie habite, though the Plot bee not naturally prone and inclining thereto.

div.head: CHAP. X.
div.p: THe Chearing of Grounds con≈øi≈øts in the curing of their infirmities,Chearing. inherent naturally or by acqui≈øition, and in the refection, and refre≈øhing their weake and langui≈øhing vertues.

Boggie.Boggie and ≈øpungie grounds are not a little ≈øetled, fa≈øtened and firmed by frequent ouer-flowing them with Fords or Land-flouds,A Paradox. affording a fatte and ≈ølimie ≈øub≈øtance or ≈ølubbe.
Stiffe-Clay.The ≈øtiffe colde Clay craues A≈øhes, e≈øpecially of roots ≈øtocked vp, Chaulke, Sea-≈øand, Malt du≈øt ≈øowen thinne on the tilth, lime incorporated with Stable-dung, ≈øalt.

Soal-bound.Cru≈øt-clung and Soale-bound ≈øoyles craue Caruage for pre≈øt and peculiar Gaole deliuerie, this lightens and loo≈øeth the ≈øoyle, and enlargeth and prepares way to the operation of the radicall humour, and con≈øequently ≈øerues in lieu of Compo≈øt.

At
que leuem ≈øtipulam crepitantibus vrere flammis:

But generally all grounds, be they neuer ≈øo barren, are much bettered by burning the dryed heapes of the turffe or ≈øwarth delued, howed, pared, or plowed vp and dried, and after ≈øpread all ouer the excoriated Tilth, whether it worke as afore≈øaid, or that according to Plinie, it burnes vp and de≈øtroies the Seminarie of gra≈ø≈øe and w√©edes, which would robbe and depriue the ≈øoyle of the rich Iuices and vertues which ≈øhould f√©ede the graine.

In the North of Ireland,Kreatings. they do with much conuenience, by kreating & ≈øhifting their Boolies froÃÑ ≈ø√©ed-fur til harue≈øt b√©e inned, both depa≈øture & ≈øoile their grounds, and pre≈øerue their graine from de≈øtruction by their cattell, and them from the Wolfe and Wood-kerne.

And Plinie reports that A≈øhes are in ≈øuch reque≈øt, for ≈øoylings n√©ere vnto Po, that they burne their Hor≈øe-dung to make them; but w√©e are too wi≈øe, holding it ridiculous to innouate, nay to imitate any thing not approoued by continual practi≈øe, how≈øoeuer we haue authenticke records from antiquities to animate vs thereunto.

Rich Soyles.W√©e willingly wi≈øh the fruition of ≈øoiles parallell to the Territories of Bi ‚Ä¢ acium in Affricke, which is ≈øo plyable to the Plow, that after a good ground ≈øhowre, a ≈øorry A≈ø≈øe and a ≈øilly old Trot, may roundly trot away with the T√©eme, and ≈øo plentifull in production, that it y√©eldes increa≈øe one hundred and fifty folde, but w√©e would grudge at the ≈øtubborne≈ø≈øe of the ground in a dry ≈øea≈øon, when w√©e found it ≈øcarce tillable with a ≈øtrong T√©eme of Oxen.

Or we could plau≈øibly approoue the light & ea≈øie Tilage, and rich Graynage, by Winterton in Norfolke: the Au≈øtrian ≈øoyle tilled with a ≈øingle hor≈øe; the fruitfull Plaines of Podolia where they ≈øow but euery other
y√©ere (the ≈øhaked corne ≈øeruing (like Rapes) for the ≈øecond ≈ø√©edage) the Hungarian treble harue≈øt, the fertile Meddowes of Komora (Iled with Danubius) which produces gra≈ø≈øe man-high, yet farre ≈øhort of the Meade vnder a Bourne n√©ere to Sali≈øbury, where the production extendes to ≈øixt√©ene foote.

The Meades of Interamna, y√©elding y√©erely foure Mathes of Hay, &c. but we would not with like alacrity imitate the indu≈øtrious paines of the ingenious Chimi≈øts, who by their diligent and intentiue hu≈øbanding their fertile fieldes, ≈øupport their ≈øtrangely populous Territories in farre greater wealth and plenty, then can be deriued from their trebled fruitage and afluent vintage, without their own extraordinary indu≈øtry and diligence.

In barren and harde Countries,1. Lime. wee are force perforce vrged to ≈øome indu≈øtry more then ordinary: As in the Countries of Salop, Denbigh, Flint, &c. they fetch Lime ≈øtone foure or fiue miles, to burne for battleing, and Sea-≈øand ≈øixe miles to ≈øcatter on their Tilthes, in Cornewall, Deuon, Somer≈øet, &c. div.head: CAP. II.
div.p: RE≈øpicient Situation hath dependance vpon Boundage and Neighbourage.Boundage.

For Coa≈øtage as Ea≈øt, Southea≈øt, South, &c.Coa≈øtage. it is in≈øeperably incident to all Boundage, as the mo≈øt Materiall and E≈ø≈øentiall part thereof, and in the recording thereof a vigilant and circum≈øpect care is required to preuent errors.

div.head: CHAP. III.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: Proportion.PRoportion con≈øi≈øts in the generall Modell and partiticular Modulets of the Plot, and procreats Men≈øuration and Content.

The Wadd is delineated either to a marke in ≈øight or out of ≈øight.Wadding.
If the Fir≈øt; let the Chaine-leaders Wadd vpon the marke by ≈øome intermediall eminence and at the ≈øetting down of euery pricke, let each man waue his mate into the right Wadd.

If out of ≈øight and in Champion not much ≈øwelling,To a Place not in view. it is expedient to place two A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, the one at the marke, and the other at the eminente≈øt Medium, and then your ≈øelfe ≈øtanding at (or directly beyond or ≈øhort) the ≈øtation giuen, and the fir≈øt A≈ø≈øi≈øtant erecting ≈øome vi≈øible obiect, waft the Wadders into the Wadd. The like by Night with lanthorne or Torch-light. Or from ≈øome eminent Mount or tran≈øcendence (beyond the marke and in the ≈øame exten≈øion) ≈øurmounting or Surueying the whole tract, pur≈øue the Wadd.

But if the place cannot bee brought within view, in≈øtrumentalize the tract at Randon, the difference of inter≈øection, found by protracting the trauer≈øe or by angular compari≈øon, ≈øhewes the point or degr√©e to be pur≈øued.

Now for remote lines the operation is produced by the doctrine of Triangles, one ≈øide and two angles,Emin√πs. or one angle and two ≈øides being giuen; As to in≈øtrumentalize a di≈øtance, fir≈øt point-forth two competent ≈øtations, and from the fir≈øt quantulate the angle betwixt the marke and ≈øecond ≈øtation, and at the ≈øecond ≈øtation take
the angle betwixt the fir≈øt Station and marke: Now the ≈øolution may be wrought either by Calculation or Proiection.Calculation.
The fir≈øt depends vpon the knowledge of Sines and Tangents, and is founded vpon this Theoreme.

p.hi: In all right-lined Triangles the mutuall proportion of one Latus to another, is ≈øuch, as the Sines re≈øpecting their Angles are proportionall.

div.p: But for as much as this conclu≈øion is more familiarly found out by protraction, I will deferre, the Propo≈øition vntill another time.

By Proiection: Protract or proiect fir≈øt a line repre≈øentig the ≈øtationall di≈øtance,Proiection. and from each extreame extend a line including an angle equall to the peculiar angle found: the inter≈øection of the≈øe two lines demon≈øtrates the marke, and the di≈øtances are manife≈øted by the Scale.
The ≈øame rea≈øon ≈øerues for heights and depthes.
And by the continued progre≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch operations the Plots and Mapps of landes, tenements, Cities Townes and Countries are produced, &c.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: Plotting.THe Plotting of lands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions comprehends their Topographicall and Mathematicall De≈øcription, and Con≈øi≈øts in Delineation & Tricking.
Delineation is conuer≈øant in pourtraying the Types, Surfaces, and Scheames of the Subiect and Adiunct.Delineation

And for exact working of both the≈øe, the Plaine-Table is mo≈øt accomodate: for the v≈øe whereof and of other in≈øtrumm ‚Ä¢ ts there are peculiar Treati≈øes extant, and therefore I will onely touch ≈øome fewe Rules in briefe.

p.hi: To Plot with Plaine-Table.

div.p: At each alternate angle produce diagonalls for plant-lines to the antegrade ≈øtation, and ≈øo compa≈ø≈øe the Plot.

To Rectifie the ≈øtationall line

div.p: From the mids of the Chorde-extend a perpendicular to ye Arch, or proiect a Triangle by producing 2.Irregulars. Crures from the Chords extreames: a iudicious eye (rectified with the≈øe men≈øurations may (ad vnguem) pricke downe the Delineations.

p.hi: The be≈øt way to expedite the exact Plotting of mixte irregulars, and con≈øequently of any Fielde.

div.p: Plant not the Table at euery Angle,Generall. but to preuent pu≈ø≈øing and to a≈ø≈øure a iu≈øt clo≈øing, extend from ≈øome fewe Maine Angles (or competent ≈øtations in the Plot) Ba≈øe lines (≈øecants, contingents, parallels, &c.) for Boundaries or deleble Plant-lines, and from conuenient di≈øtances in the ≈øame, di≈øtantiate euery By, di≈øper≈øed in the Plot, and ≈øo pricke forth the Angles, Curues and Deuiations.
For Delineating of Adiuncts, as Edifices and other erections, the Pro≈øpectiue gla≈ø≈øe is facil & compendious, but for want thereof take this generall Rule.
Proiect all Plumbe-lines in Parallelizme perpendicular to a Parallel or ≈øuppo≈øed Common Ba≈øe of con≈øpicuous eminence.Plotting „Äà‚óä„Äâ Archi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ture

So the Ba≈øe of the Building proiected in due Site, the modulets right angles by peculiar erection retaine like qualitie in Plano ex oppo≈øito, but ex obliquo they doe alternately appeare acute and obtu≈øe. Other Delineations dependant ≈øucc√©ed by con≈øequence, and the eye by ≈øerious ob≈øeruation of ≈øtationall a≈øpect may with facilitie giue the Vmbrage: but the Tran≈øpo≈øition and fore-≈øhortening of ≈øome lines require more particular Rules, which with diuers other matters I am h√©ere con≈øtrained to cut-off, lea≈øt this worke intended for a Breuiat, ≈øhould grow vnto too great a Volume.
And therefore for this time this ≈øhall ≈øuffize for Delineation.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: Tricking.THe Tricking of Plots con≈øi≈øts in Complements, and Compartiments.
Complements comprehende the Flie or Flies, Scale and Compa≈ø≈øe, Kalender, Characters, Colours, &c.
The Flie.The Flie is a Card diuided into eight, ≈øixt√©ene, thirty two equall parts in the Limbe with competent extention to ≈øhew the Meridian and Coa≈øtages of the Plot.

Meridian.Meridians are diuers wayes found-out, but mo≈øt ≈øp√©edily and exactly by helpe of a Dyall, or by ≈øtriking a line vpon your Table, or erecting poles vpon your Plot in a right line, directing to the Cyno≈øure or Pole≈øtarre, when it is perpendicular to Alliot the Thilhor≈øe of Charles-Waine.

Otherwi≈øe at the Sunnes fir≈øt cutting of the Horizon, ≈øtrike a line towards the ≈øame vpon your Table and erect a marke in the field-line: At the Sunnes going
downe (the ≈øame day) plant your Table as before by helpe of the marke erected, and ≈øtrike another line to the Sunne from the fir≈øt point: Now de≈øcribe a Circle vpon this ≈øtationall point to cut the two extended lines at equall lengthes: The Diameter that mediates the Arch of each Sector is the Meridian, &c.
The Scale and Compa≈ø≈øe are no le≈ø≈øe requi≈øite,Scale. and may be flori≈øhed with Fruitage or Imagery.
The Kalender or Index ≈øerues for a Directory to expedite the intimation of particulars with ≈øignance of due Characters.Kalender.
The Colours would bee appropriated and ≈øuited to the ≈øeuerall Modulets of the Plot to di≈øtingui≈øh their Natures, Tenures, Owners,Colours. or ≈øuch like:Arable. ‚Äî As
Arable for Corne may be da≈øhed with a pale Strawcolour compounded of Yellow Oker, and White leade, or of Pincke and Verdigreece.
Meddowes may be wa≈øhed with a light Gr√©ene by taking more Verdigreece and le≈ø≈øe Pincke.Meddowes.
Pa≈øture would be put into a d√©eper Gr√©ene made of the mixture of Azure and Smalts with Pincke;Pa≈øture.
Heathes and Fennes may be di≈øtingui≈øht with deader Gr√©ene deriued from Yellow and Indico.Heathes.
Tr√©es may haue a ≈øadder Gr√©ene compo≈øed of white Leade and Verdigreece.Trees.
Barke, Blocks, Timber, Stone, &c.Barke. may bee fitted with Vmber and White.
Waies and Mud-wals, may haue white-leade with ru≈øt of Iron, or with Oker and Browne of Spaine.Waies.
Water, Siluer, Gla≈ø≈øe, Cry≈øtal,Water. &c. may be repre≈øented with Indico and Azure or blacke Leade.
Seas may haue their gr√©eni≈øh Skie-colour expre≈ø≈øed with Indico (Smalts or Azure) White leade and Verdigreece.Sea.

And thus, both the≈øe and diuers other colours with their due proportion, may with ≈ømall practi≈øe be ea≈øily
produced and multiplyed; And it will ≈øuffice to tract the Verges onely of Land-Modulets what≈øoeuer you plea≈øe to ≈øignifie thereby.
But how≈øoeuer you be≈øtow the≈øe Colours of di≈øtemper, they mu≈øt be ground and bound with Gum-water very thinne and bodile≈ø≈øe.

And it ≈øhal not be ami≈ø≈øe to pounce the ground with a Stain≈øh Graine of burnt Allome and a double quantity of pounded Ro≈ø≈øin both finely fearced and lightly pummiced, thereby to pre≈øerue the Paper or Parchment from thorowe-piercing with the Colours.
Compartiments are Blankes or Figures bordered with Anticke Bo≈øcage or Crote≈øko-woorke,Compartiments. wherein Euidences or other Memorables may be abreuiated.
And the≈øe may bee contriued in Parallelograms, Squares, Circles, Oualls, Lunaries, or other mixt or voluntary proportions compa≈ø≈øed and tricked ad libituÃÑ.
Vnder this Title may al≈øo be rainged the Lordes-Coate with Cre≈øt and Mantells.
And the≈øe Compartiments with the Scale, Carde and Kalender mu≈øt bee be≈øtowed in couuenient ≈øpare and voide places.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p: Content.HItherto of Men≈øuration: Content in generall is Couchant and Cre≈øcent.
The Couchant is either Superficiall or Solid.
The fir≈øt is of Land, Water, Board, Gla≈ø≈øe and all Surfaces and Figures.

But before wee come to entreat of the Areas of Figure, it is not immateriall to enumerate how this Superficiall Content is diuersly di≈øtingui≈øhed for Land; as into Pearches, Daies-woorkes, Roodes, Acres, Oxegangs, Yard-lands, Plow-lands, Hydes.
There be al≈øo other quantities of Land taking their denominations from our v≈øual Coine; as Fardingdeales, Obolates, Denariates, Solidates, Librates.
Foure ≈øquare Pearches make a Daies worke, 10. Daie-workes a Roode or Stong, 4. Roodes an Acre.

The Fardingdeale or Farundell (Quadrantata terrae) ≈øignifies a Roode or ¬º of an Acre,Quadrantata Terrae. ≈øo that if Obolata D ‚Ä¢ nariata, Solidata, and Librata, doe ari≈øe in proportionable graduation from Quadrantata as the moneyes do increa≈øe in valuable E≈øtimate, then mu≈øt the Obalat be ¬Ω Acre, the Denariat an Acre, the Solidat 12. acres & the Librat 240. vide Crompton luri≈ød: and Regi≈øt: Origin .1. But we read Viginti libratas terrae vel reditus in Fitzh .87. and Regi≈øt. Orig. 49. and 248. importing (it ≈ø√©emes) ≈øo much land as y√©eldes 20. s. per annum.
So you ≈øhall read further 249. Regi≈øt. Centum Solidatas terrarum tenementorum & redituum.

But for Roodes and Acres,Acrarum diuer≈øitas. they differ in Content according to the power of the extent or lineall Fall of the Pearch. Potentia rectae e≈øt quadratum. Et dupla, ratione quadrupla proportione.

Yet the Surueyor, whether he be imployed in Woodland, or Champion, in the Forre≈øt of Sh√©ere-Wood, where the Acre containes aboue 2 ¬º of Statute Acres, in Corne-wal where it amounts almo≈øt to 140. acres, or el≈øewhere, how≈øoeuer Cu≈øtomes haue accrewed, mu≈øt make his Computation by the ≈øtandard: Notwith≈øtanding that the Lords Demaines (as appeares by auncient Surueys) haue b√©ene mea≈øured by the 20.Men≈øura Maior & Minor. foote Pole called Maior Men≈øura, and the Cu≈øtomary lands by a Pole called Men≈øura Minor viz. 16. ¬Ω though ≈øome claime 18. foote¬∑ So the French Arpent or Acre containing 100.Arpent. ≈øquare Poles is laid-out in th'admea≈øurement of woodes by the 22 foot Pole, & this is called the Kings Arpent, their other lands are computated by the Pole of 20. 19 ‚Öì or 18. foot Poles.

The Oxe-gang,Bouata. Terrae. or Oxengate (according to Skene) called Bouata terrae containes after the originall repute 13. acres but we find it more or le≈ø≈øe as the cu≈øtom of the place inures, and Bouata is properly v≈øed of Lands in
Gainour viz. v≈øually plowed.
Librata Terrae. Virgata Terrae.Foure Oxe-gangs of land extend to a Pound-land (Librata terrae,) of old extent.
The Yard-land (Virgata terrae ≈øiue quatrona terrae) varies from 20, 24, 30 acres. M. Lamberd: and it is not reputed in Deme≈øne, but in Gainor, as are al≈øo fodi ‚Ä¢ a, minera, mercatus.
Carucata. Terrae.A Plow-land or Carue of land (Carucata terrae, that is, quantuÃÑ aratrum arare pote≈øt in nouali tempore:) is ≈øaid to containe 4 Yard-land at 30 acres to the Yard-land.

Hida.A Hide of Land (Hida or Hilda terrae) is ≈øaide to be ≈øuch a portion of land, as may be tilled with one teame (according to the ≈øeuerall tilthes and ≈øea≈øons) in a y√©ere and a day, and ≈øo Crompton and the Author of the new Tearmes affirme it to be 100 acres by ≈øtatute, & therby confound Hida with Carucata, or make them little different. Others ≈øay, that euery Hide of land containes 4 Plow-land at 120 acres, and 4 Hides a Knights F√©e.

Feudum Militare.A Knights F√©e (Feudum Militare) is ≈øo much Inheritance as is ≈øufficient yearely for the maintenance of a Knight, and his competent retinewe with conuenient reuenewe, which in the time of H. the 3. was 15 pound; but Sir Thomas Smith (Repub. Anglorum,) rateth it at 40 pounds per annum. But for the quantity of land, M. Camden recordes it to be 680 acres or 800 acres. After ≈øome computations it containes 5 Hydes of land, each Hyde 4 Yard-land at 24 acres.
In the Dutchie of Lanca≈øter a Knights F√©e contains 4 Hydes of land, each Hyde 4 Plow-land, each Plow-land 4 yard-land at 30 acres amounting to 1920 acres.
Cantred Baronie. Earledome.Two Knights F√©es make a Cantred, 2 Cantreds ¬Ω and ‚Öô make a Barony, one Barony and ¬Ω makes an Earledome: viz. 38400 acres.

But though the≈øe proportions of land doe not alwaies hold with their titles of honour, yet their denominations continue the originall in≈øtitution, and how≈øoeuer
they be di≈ømembred quoad quantitatem, Dignities indiui≈øible. yet the right and dignitie is indiui≈øible, in≈øomuch as if a Capitall Me≈ø≈øuage be Caput Comitatus vel Baroniae, it may not be parcelled.

And the Reliefe depends vpon the dignity (rather then the quantity) after the fir≈øt allotment,Reliefes of Dignities. viz. 100 s for a Knights F√©e, 100 Marks for a Barony, and an 100 pounds for an Earledome. Mag. Chart. But to returne to the finding out of the Areaes of Figures.
