argument.p: SECTION .III. Capitulating the Natures and Incidents to Po≈ø≈øe≈øsions, Tenures, Landes, Titles, Fees, Di≈øcents, Tenants, &c.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p: HItherto of the E≈ø≈øentiall Parts:Accidentall. Partes. the Accidentall Parts incident to Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions are comprehended vnder Propriety and Valuation.
The Propriety of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions intimates their particular ≈øtate and condition,Proprietie. and may be deuided into Vocall and Euidential.
Vocall Propriety denotates the Properties of particulars by due Appellation,Vocall which is either Nominate or Cognominate.

The fir≈øt is deriued from the Kinde and Species of the Particulars, and that either Generall;Nominate. as Vp-land
and Maritime, Woodland and Champion, Molland and Fen-land: Or Speciall; as Wealdes, Woulds, Plaines, Downes, Vales, Vallies, Mountaines, Fels, Hilles, Bogs, Bathes, Spawes, Mo≈ø≈øes, Loughs, Moores, Fennes, Woodes, Cop≈øes, Heathes, Mar≈øhes, Meddowes, Pa≈øture, Arable.

Cognominate.The Second deduces deriuation from Forme, Site, Climate, Obiect, Sea≈øon, Per≈øon, Action or other circum≈øtance; as Harpe-Clo≈øe, Mountacute, Gilden-Vale Diffrin Cluyd, Sali≈øbury Plaine, We≈øt-woodes, Vale of Belvoir, Lammas Pa≈øture, Bel-Acre, Beaumeade, Nightingale Lane, Lough Erno.
So much for the Vocall Proprietie of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions.

div.head: CAHP. II.
div.p: Evidentiall. Proprietie.EVidentiall Proprietie decyphers the qualities and attributes coincident to the Po≈ø≈øident and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: and in the proce≈ø≈øe hereof the Legall part of Suruey is mo≈øt eminent.
Po≈ø≈øident.In the Po≈ø≈øident or Feudatarie his Title and Di≈øcent mu≈øt be intimated.
His Title re≈øpects either Dignitie of Birth or Calling; Or Right of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
Dignitie.Title of Dignitie; as King, Prince, Duke, Arch-Bi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, Abbot, Prior, Marque≈ø≈øe, Earle, Vicount, Baron, Knight, E≈øquire, Gentleman, Yeoman, Artificer, Labourer.
Right.Right of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion may be deuided into perpetuall and Terminall.
Perpetuall is either Allodium or Feudum.
Allodium Allodium is an entire propertie and perpetuall Right in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions without dependance; and this is proper ≈øolely to the King in Right of his Crowne.

And all the Crowne land within this Realme in the
daies of the Saxon King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor are called Auncient Deme≈øne. Kitch. 98. Booke Tit. Deme≈øne.

And the≈øe Landes in the generall Suruey called Doomes-day Booke (made according to Gerua≈øius Tilburen≈øis and Ingulfus, in the time of William the Conquerour) remaining in the Exchequer,Terra Regis are among≈øt others) recorded vnder the Title of Terra Regis.
Fitzh. inferres (13. and 14. Na. Br.) that no landes are to be accounted Auncient Demaine,Auncient. Demaine. but ≈øuch as are held in Socage.

All other Landes within the Realme are called Frank-F√©e,Frank. Free. (Feudum Francum ≈øeu liberum) which is defined to be a Tenure in F√©e-≈øimple, of landes pleadable at the Common-law, in oppo≈øition to the other, who≈øe tenents cannot be impleaded out of the L. Court.

Feudum is that which is held of a ≈øuperiour by Seruice, Rent or both:Feudum. Or Feudum or F√©e is a Right con≈øi≈øting in the per≈øon of the true heire, or of ≈øome other that by iu≈øt Title hath purcha≈øed or acquired the ≈øame: vide Bracton.
And this is alwaies diriued either Immediately or Mediately from the Crowne.
The fir≈øt is where ye F√©e re≈øides ≈øtil in the fir≈øt Feoff√©e.
The other is where the Kings Feudataries doe againe enfeoff√©e others.Feifz and Arrierfiefz. The French terme the fir≈øt of the≈øe Feifz and the other Arrierfiefz.
Feudum is either F√©e-≈øimple or F√©e-taile.
F√©e-≈øimple is an ab≈øolute ≈øei≈øure to the Feudatarie and his heires for euer.Feodum ≈øimplex.

And though many Feudi≈øts doe holde that Feudatarius hath not an entire property in his F√©e, I may not conclude vpon Iacobutius his in≈øinuated probabilities, that the≈øe F√©es (or ≈øome of them) were at their fir≈øt creation temporary and not perpetuall and hereditary.

p.hi: Tantum aevi longinqua valet ≈øolidare vetu≈øtas.

div.p: Feodum. Taliatum.F√©e-taile or F√©e Expectant is a conditionall ≈øeizure to the Feudatary and his heires with limitation, and is either Generall or Speciall.
General, is where a man is ≈øeized of land to him≈øelfe and the heires of his body for euer.
Speciall, where the man and his wife are ≈øeized of lands to them≈øelues and the heires of their two bodies.

The nature of this F√©e is implyed by the ≈øignification of the word Talliatum which the Normans make Tailler, and in Latine it is as much as Scindere: ≈øo this Feodum or Ius Talliatum doth ab≈øcinde and cut-off the before-General ≈øucce≈ø≈øions re≈øtraining them to the particular Heires of Families, yet the locall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions are v≈øuall tran≈ø-ferred from one family to another, but Dignities whether Datiue or Natiue are therewith neither conferred nor auferred.
Terminable Right.Terminall Right is either an E≈øtate for life, as the Dowagers, Graunt√©es for life; &c. Or for Yeares, as by Lea≈øe, Mortgage, &c.
Tenant.And in re≈øpect of the≈øe and other ≈øeueral Rights, the Tenant is diuersly taken and vnder≈øtood, and implies a≈øwell the Feudatary or Owner, as the Farmor or Termer.
Dutie.Tenant in the fir≈øt ≈øignification ≈øometimes imports duety of Tenurage: as Tenant by Knight-≈øeruice, Socage, Tenant in Villenage, Burgage, Frank-F√©e, Tenens per Catapultam, tenens Nativus.
Euidence.Sometimes it intimates his Euidence: as Tenant by Charter, Copie of Court-Roll, Verge.
Limitation.Somtimes it implies the extent of his e≈øtate of right; as Tenant in F√©e-≈øimple, F√©e-taile, at will of the Lord according to the cu≈øtome of the Manour or by common Lawe.

Sometimes it beares relation to the L. of the F√©e; as Tenant in chiefe, very Tenant, viz. holding immediatly of his L. Me≈øn. Tenant Parauaile, viz. the lowe≈øt
Tenants, & mo≈øt remote from the L. Paramount.
There is al≈øo ioint-tenant, ≈øole-tenant, tenant in Common.

Tenant ≈øignifying the Termer is diuer≈øified according to the exigence of the efficient cau≈øes of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions;Termer. as Tenant in Dowre, by Courte≈øie, by Will, Lea≈øe, Copie, Extent, Elegit, Execution, Statute Merchant, or of the Staple, &c. And thus much for the Title.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: DI≈øcent is the deuolution of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions deriued to the Heire apparant from his Aunce≈øtrie,Di≈øcent. by vnauoidable Right and Succe≈ø≈øion.
And this Di≈øcent is either of Bloud or of Inheritance.
Di≈øcent of Bloud is either Lineal or Collaterall.
Lyneal Di≈øcent is conueyed downe in a right line from Grand-father, Father, Sonne, Nephew,Lineall. &c. And here is produced an Heire Generall.
Collateral Di≈øcent ≈øprings foorth of the ≈øide of the whole Blood or Kinne; as Grand-fathers brother,Collaterall Fathers brother, &c. And in this ca≈øe the Heire is ≈øaide to be Speciall.
This Di≈øcent of Blood is retriued by deriuage of Pedegr√©es from Aunce≈øtrie,Pedigrees. by inherent Birth-right and lawfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øion.

Di≈øcent of Inheritance is deduced by deriuing Sequences of D√©edes from the Crowne,Sequences or from him that had Nouell F√©e. And both the≈øe are very requi≈øite to be intimated for the manife≈øtation of the Validities of E≈øtates, whether the right dimaine from Heritage or forraigne acqui≈øition.
And hitherto of the Po≈ø≈øident: It followes to entreat of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.IN the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Nature and Tenure require to be iudiciou≈øly di≈øcu≈ø≈øed and recorded.

Eminence.For the Nature 'tis expedient to notifie the Eminence thereof, whether Grande, as Honours, Courts, Ca≈øtels, Manours, Seignories, Forre≈øts, Cha≈øes, Parks, Deme≈ønes: Or Petty, as Graunges, Farmes, Tenements, Me≈ø≈øuages, Cotages, Curtilages, Lofts, Crofts, Commons.

Incidents.In both the≈øe kinds diligent and particular enquirie mu≈øt be had of their Incidents, by Royalties, Prerogatiues, Iuri≈ødictions, Franchi≈øes, Priuiledges, Liberties, Rights, &c. conferred vpon them by Act of Parliament, Statute, Charter, letters Patents, Graunts, or acquired and confirmed by cu≈øtome or pre≈øcription.
Lord≈øhips.Hence comes the Lord≈øhip Marcher or Royall v≈øing iura Regalia. Vide Stowe 176.

Courts.And Forre≈øts haue their Courts of Attachment, Swanimote, Eyre or Iu≈øtice Seate. So Markets, Faires, & Court of Pie-Powders for Faires. Court-L√©ete (Law-day, or View of Franck Pledge) Court Baron. Al≈øo Wrecks, Swannage, Warrenage, Commonage, Pi≈øeage, &c.

Immunities.Immunities and Exemptions from Theolonie, Pontage, Picage, Murage, Pannage, Pa≈ø≈øage, Tranage, La≈øtage, Chiminage, Stallage, Caiage, &c. of all which Tenentes Honoris & Dominij de Richemonde per con≈øu etudinem Angliae ≈øunt quieti per totum Regnum: ≈øo other Honours haue their Priuiledges, as Ampthil, Tickhil, Follingham, &c.

Auncient Demei≈øme.The Tenants of Manours holding fr√©ely by Charter in ancient Demei≈øne cannot be impleaded, nor empanelled
vpon Enque≈øts out of the ≈øame Manour, and they are Toll-fr√©e for all things concerning their ≈øu≈øtenance and hu≈øbandrie, and exempt from contribution towards the expen≈øes of Knights of the Parliament or Shiere. Vid. Fitzh. Na. br. 14. & 128.
Infeoffing with Toll,Toll. implies Fr√©edome from Cu≈øtome, &c.
With Caruage, from taxation by Carues.
With Bruckboote, from repairing and reedifying of Bridges, with Burghboote, from the like for Ca≈øtels.
Foote-geld implies a Priuiledge to k√©epe Dogges within the Forre≈øt not expeditated or lawed ≈øans controule.Foote-geld.
Horne-geld fr√©edome from taxe for Horne-bea≈øts there.
Waiues, Weifes, or waiued goods,Waiues. import all goods and chattels, which being ≈øtolne, are left or for≈øaken by the thiefe in his fugacie.
Infangthef enables the L. of the Manour to iudge of Felons enhabiting within the F√©e. And Vtfangthef, Infangthef. to iudge, or (at lea≈øt) to execute iudgement of Felons apprehended within the F√©e.

For Accrewments to the L. of the Manour by Felons,Felonies. not onely their goods both Reall and Per≈øonal are forfaited, but al≈øo their lands not entailed e≈øcheat to the Lord (Po≈øt annum diem & va≈øtum) except in Glouce≈øter≈øhiere where the lands reuert to the right heire after the Kings y√©ere and day. Al≈øo in the Tenure of Gauelkinde in Kent, where the father to the Bough, the ≈øonne to the Plough.
Baronies infeoffed with Theame alias Them, Theame. haue power to di≈øpo≈øe of Villaines their Children, goods, and Chattels.
Abi≈øher≈øing, alias Mi≈øher≈øing, Abi≈øher≈øing, implies both forfaitures and Amerciaments of all tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions within the F√©e, and al≈øo the immunity from like penalties.
Blood-wit.Blood-wit confers all Amerciaments of Courts for effu≈øion of blood.
E≈øtouers.E≈øtouers granted out of Woods or Forre≈øts, include Hou≈øe-boote, Hay-boote, and Plow-boote.

div.head: CAP. V.
div.p: Tenure.OF the Nature of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions I haue ≈øpoken ≈øomewhat: The Tenure of Lands and Tenements, is the manner whereby they are helde of their Lords. Grande Cu≈øt. Cap. 28.
In euery Tenure the Confinage & Condition therof are remarkable.
Confinage.The Confinage ≈øhewes to what Lord, Honour, Ca≈øtell, Manour, &c. the Seruice and Suitage (whereunto the Lands and Tenements are lyable) is due.
Condition.The condition intimates the Nature of the ≈øeruice or duty which the Tenant, by rea≈øon of his F√©e, oweth vnto the Lord.

Seruice.This Seruice is by Hotoman defined to be Munus ob≈øequij clientelaris; and this mu≈øt be of ancient Commencement and continuance, ≈øith it is not now erigible or to be created (but by the Kings prerogatiue) as parcel of a Manour, though it may by contract be e≈øtabli≈øhed in a kinde of Seignorie in Gro≈ø≈øe.
Manour.For a Manour is a Seignorie or Dominium con≈øi≈øting of Deme≈ønes and Seruices of long continuance; and the≈øe may be comprehended vnder parts E≈ø≈øentiall and Accidentall.

Court Extinct.Here note, if the Lord ≈øo di≈ømember his Manour, as that hee leaues not Fr√©e-holders, or if all the Fr√©e-holders ≈øaue one doe e≈øcheate, then is hee di≈øabled to k√©epe a Court Baron for want of Suitors.

Non-Parcels vnited.Land may holde of a Manour by certaine Seruices
which may be Parcel of the Manour, and the land Non-Parcel; but by E≈øcheat the Seruice is extingui≈øht, and the land comes in place and becomes Parcell in due con≈øolidation.
But forraigne land cannot be vnited to a Manour,Manour diui≈øible. yet may a Manour be deuided into diuers by Partition of Coparceners.

Nor can two di≈øtinct Manours by practi≈øe be made one in perfect Vnion,Not vniable. how≈øoeuer ≈øuch an innouation continued without contradiction, may in proce≈ø≈øe of time become to be reputed one in name and v≈øe, there being no Record extant to the contrarie: Yet one Manour holding of an other, may by E≈øcheat be annexed to the ≈øame, and ≈øo be con≈øolidated and become one in v≈øe.

But to returne: Deme≈ønes are all ≈øuch lands,Deme≈ønes. as haue b√©ene time out of minde helde in occupation and manurance, together with the Site of the Man≈øion or Manour Hou≈øe (called in ≈øome places Berries, Halls, Manour places, Courts and Court-hou≈øes) for maintenance of the Lords hou≈øe.

The≈øe Deme≈ønes were called of the Saxons (who had the ≈øub≈øtance, though not the name of Manours) Inlandt (and by Bracton (lib. 4.) Bord-lands) and the Seruices Vtlandt in oppo≈øition,Out-landt how re≈øtraind. though it may in ≈øome ≈øort be re≈øtrained to comprehend onely Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments y√©elding Rents of A≈ø≈øize (viz. originall and ≈øet in certainty) as for Fr√©e-hold, Copie-hold,Rents of A≈ø≈øize. or Cu≈øtomarie land; all which are Parcel in Seruice.
For the Diui≈øion of Seruices,Seruices deuided. they may be all comprehended vnder Chiualrie and Soccage.

Chiualrie, or Seruitium Militare, Chiualry. is a Tenure or Seruice, obliging the Feudatarie per≈øonally to performe vnto his Lord ≈øome honorable or Martiall office; And this confers to the Lord (the Heire being in Non-age at the Fathers death) the Reall Seruices of Ward≈øhip,
Marriage and Reliefe, in lieu of the Per≈øonal Seruice, which the Heire in regard of minority is not able to execute.
Chiualry or Knight-≈øeruice is deuided into Regall and Common.

Regall. Chiualry. Capite.Regall Chiualrie is ≈øolely confineable to the King, and is properly called Sergeantie. And this holdes either m√©erely and immediately of the King as of his Crowne (which is a Corporation and Seignorie in Gro≈ø≈øe) and is then further called Tenure in Capite or Chiefe: Or mediately of the King by rea≈øon of ≈øome Honour, Manour, Ca≈øtel. Fitzh. Kitch.
Sergeantie.Sergeantie (Sergeantia or Seriantia) is either Grande or Petit.
Grande. Grande Sergeantie is where Lands are helde of the King by ≈øome noble Seruice, performeable by the Tenant per≈øonally.
Petit. Petit Sergeantie is where Lands are held of the King, to y√©eld him annually ≈øome ≈ømall military furniture towards his warres.

Common Chiualry.Common Chiualrie is that Seruice which may indifferently be confined to the Prince, or to a common per≈øon; and is called E≈øcuage (viz. Shield-≈øeruice) which is either Vncertaine or Certaine.E≈øcuage.

Vncertaine. E≈øcuage vncertaine is of two ≈øorts: Fir≈øt, where the Tennant is Tenure-bound at his owne co≈øt and charges, to follow his Lord in the Kings warres, or to ≈øend a ≈øufficient man in his ≈øteade, there to continue according to the proportion of his F√©e: viz. after the rate of 40. daies for a Knights F√©e.
Ca≈øtel-ward.Secondly, where he is bound by him≈øelfe or his Deputy to defend a Ca≈øtell, ≈øo oft as it ≈øhall come to his cour≈øe or turne, and is called in this ca≈øe Ca≈øtel-warde. Ma. Cha. 20.

Certaine.E≈øcuage Certaine is where the Tenant is ≈øet at a certain pecuniarie charge (viz. 20 ≈øhillings for a Knights
F√©e) in lieu of ≈øuch vncertaine Seruices, as afore≈øaide. And this l√©e≈øeth the nature of Knight-≈øeruice, and is in effect Socage (though not m√©erely. becau≈øe it ≈ømels not of the Plowe) though it ≈øtill retaine the name of E≈øcuage. Na. Br. 84. Litl.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p: SOccage (Soccagium) is a Tenure of Lands obliging the Feudatary to the performance of certaine inferiour and hu≈øbandly ≈øeruices vnto the Lord of the F√©e,Soccage. ≈øans Ward≈øhip, mariage, Reliefe.
Soccage is al≈øo capable of the di≈øtinction of Chiefe and Common.
Soccage in Chiefe or Capite, Chiefe. is that which holdes immediatly of the King as of his Crowne. Praerog. 41.
Common Soccage is that which holdes of the King or ≈øome other Capitall Lord, by meanes of ≈øome Manour. Ibidem.
Soccage is either Franck (liberum) or Ba≈øe (Villanum.)
Franke Soccage is where in lieu of ≈øeruice in kinde a≈øumme of money is paid to the Lord.Franke.
Ba≈øe Soccage is a Seruile kinde of Tenure,Ba≈øe. and is deuided into Villanum Soccagium, and Purum Villenagium.
The fir≈øt is, where a determinat Seruice is performable by rea≈øon of the Tenement, and not of the per≈øon of the Tenant.
The other is where the Feudatarie is lyable to vncertaine and indeterminat Seruice at the ab≈øolute and in≈øtant will and demaund of the Lord.Villenage. Bracton. & Na. Br. 94.

Yet may a man ≈øans impeach of fr√©edome (in regard of his per≈øon) hold in Pure Villenage;The per≈øon, nor the Freehold impeached. Nor is liberum tenementum impeached to him that holdes it in Villano
Soccagio, if it be to him and to his heires. Bracton.
There be other branches of Soccage, as Burgage; Frank-Almoine.
Copy-hold.And Copy-hold (≈øaith Kitchin 80) is a ba≈øe Tenure, and was originally called Villenage, Fitz. 12.
Meere Copy-hold.But (to retaine the moderne appellation) ≈øome of this is M√©ere Copy-hold, and e≈øcheats forthwith to the Lord by Felony. Kitch. 81.

And ≈øome is of more eminence, and held by Verge in auncient Demei≈øne, according to the Cu≈øtome of the Manor, being in effect a kinde of Fr√©e-hold (though reputed Copy) and y√©elds to the King Annum, diem & Va≈øtum vpon Felony.
Some Copy-holds are fineable at the Lords will; and ≈øome only are lyable to a certain rate,Fines. and this is a kind of inheritance called Cu≈øtomary, not ≈øimply at the will of the Lord.

But there is a kinde of Cu≈øtomary Land of the Ancient Dutchy of Cornewall and other places,Cu≈øtomary. where the Tenants haue no Tran≈øcripts of the entries of their admittances;Folk-land. And this was called Folke-land, and the Tenants may be termed Tenants by Court-Roll, according to the Cu≈øtome of the Manour.
But where the Tenants are, by rea≈øon of the Tran≈øcripts of admittances, called Tenants by Copy of Court-Roll, there the Land is Charter-land or Bockland.Bock-land. Kitch. 86.89.
For the Definition of a Copy-holder, reade We≈øt in his Symbol. 1. parte. 646.
And for the various Cu≈øtomes of Copy-holders in ≈øeueral Manours, 'tis as n√©edle≈ø≈øe as endle≈ø≈øe to capitulate or enumerate them in this Tractate.

But both m√©ere Copy-holde may be conuerted into F√©e,Conuer≈øion of Fees. and likewi≈øe F√©es changed from their fir≈øt in≈øtitution by feofment; as out of Chiualry for certaine y√©erely Rent into F√©e-Farme, ≈øans further duty than is ≈øpecially
compri≈øed in the Graunt, except Fealty alone, which by probability is ≈øtill on foote, becau≈øe it is in≈øeperably incident to all Tenures.Fealty. For who≈øoeuer is inve≈øted in F√©e, though in the fr√©e≈øt maner, holdeth perfidem & fiduciam, that is, by Fealty at lea≈øt. Smith Rep. Anglorum. 3.
And Dwarenus ≈øaith, that Fidelitas e≈øt ≈øub≈øtantia Feudi.

F√©e-Farme is a F√©e,Fee-Farme. and importeth a perpetuity to the Inue≈øt√©e and his heires, for an annuall Rent of the third or fourth part of the Value. Fitzh. 210. But if the Rent re≈øerued be behinde and vnpaide for the ≈øpace of two y√©eres, then may the Feoffour or his heires by Action recouer the Lands as their Deme≈ønes. Britton. 66. And land thus held comes n√©ere to the Nature of Ager vectigalis among≈øt the Ciuillians.

q.l: And hitherto of the Propriety of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions:
It remaines to intreate of their Valuations.

div.head: THE SYNOPSIS OR EPITOME OF SVRVEY METHODIZED.
SECTION .IIII.

argument.p: How Po≈ø≈øe≈øsions are to be valued by rea≈øon of their ≈øeuerall i≈ø≈øues, Rents, Perqui≈øites, Priuiledges and other profits, with particular re≈øpect to their Reuenewes and Repri≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p: THE Valuation of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions con≈øi≈øts in the due E≈øtimate and Prizall of all Parts and Particulars E≈ø≈øentially and Accidentally thereunto belonging:Valuation. And to the exact performance hereof both the Materiall and Legall Parts are very requi≈øite.
This Valuation is either Reiterant or Determinant.
Reiterant Valuation depends vpon the exact knowledge both of the Reuenewes and Repri≈øes.

Reuenewes.Vnder Reuenewes (or E≈øplees after Ingham) I comprehend all and ≈øingular Rents, Seruices, I≈ø≈øues, and profits accrewing and renewing to the Feudi≈øt or Po≈ø≈øident by, through or by rea≈øon of F√©es and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions.
And the≈øe Reuenewes may be ≈øaid to be Conuentuall and Incident.
Conuentuall Reuenewes comprize al Rents both in E≈ø≈øe and in Po≈ø≈øe.
Rents.Rents in E≈ø≈øe are Receipts certaine or couenanted, and payable at daies and termes limited: and they are either Proper or Improper.

Proper.Rents Proper (whether Rent-≈øeruice, Rent-charge, or Rent-Secke) may be for Landes, tenements, Pa≈øture, Engines, Mils, Mines, Quarries, Warrens, Fi≈øhing, Fowling, Wood-≈øayles, Heath, Fur≈øe, Turbarie Ma≈øtage, (of B√©ech, Oake, Holme, &c.) Herbage, Broovage, &c. And Rent-Proui≈øion, as Beifes, Muttons, Veni≈øon, Fi≈øh, Fowle, Graine and other voluntarie re≈øeruations vpon graunts or e≈øtates for liues or yeres.

Improper.Rents Improper are where, of an vncertaine and ca≈øual commodity, a certaine Rent or Receipt is by contract created & rai≈øed: as for Licences, Swan-markes, Profits of Faires, Markets, Courts, Cu≈øtomes, Tollage, Pontage, Caiage, Cranage, Ferriage, Boonage, &c.

Po≈ø≈øe.Conuentuall Reuenewes in Po≈ø≈øe are all i≈ø≈øues and aduantages ari≈øing of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions not demi≈øed (though Rentable) and therefore nece≈ø≈øarily valueable by E≈øtimate: as Demaine-Landes, Timber, Manuells, Wa≈øts, &c.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: Incident.INcident Reuenewes are either profitable as Perqui≈øites, or Parallels to profits.
Perqui≈øites may be diuided into Renouant and Dormant.Perqui≈øites.
Renouant Perqui≈øites are Accrewments acquired by Increa≈øe and Ca≈øualty.
Increa≈øe comprehends all profits deriued from the Pregnance and Production of the Earth.Pregnance.
Of the fir≈øt ≈øort are Stones, Metalline Oares and Mineralles vt ≈øupra.

Of the ≈øecond ≈øort are Wines, Pirry, Cider, Hony,Production. Waxe, Bombace, Raw-≈øilkes, Hops, Sumach, Pitch, Tarre, Campheire, Opponax, Taccamahacca, Caranna, Ma≈øticke, and other Gums: Likewi≈øe Drugs, as Mechoacan, Kermez, Methium, Alkanet, Agaricke, Amber-Gr√©ece, Acacia, Lignum Aloes, Sa≈ø≈øafras, Spikenard, Rubarbe: Al≈øo Mu≈øke, Ciuet, Ben, Beniamin, Ca≈øtoreum, Cantarides, Cocheneil, with other Simples Fruite, Rootes. And Furres as Armins, Sables, Minivers, Lewzernes, Martins, Beauers, &c.
By Ca≈øualty are intended all duties and ≈øeruices that be Appurtenant and Appendant to a Manour,Ca≈øualtie. whether it be Capitall or Non-Capitall.
Vnder Appurtenants, may be rainged all Royalties Prerogatiues, Iuri≈ødictions, Franchi≈øes, Priuiledges,Appurtenants. Liberties, Seruices, Cu≈øtomes, &c.

And all emoluments and aduantages deriueable from them: Perqui≈øites of Courts; as Pleas, Fines, Amerceaments, Heriots, (Seruice, Cu≈øtome, Couenant) Releifes, Aydes, Farewels, Waiues, E≈øtraies, Deodands, goods of Felons and Fugitiues (by ≈øpeciall graunt) coÃÑ morant in the Manour, Forfeitures, E≈øcheates, Wards (in Non-age, Idiocy Lunacy) Marriages, Villaines, Trea≈øure-Troue: Warrens of Birds, Conies, Hares, Commons of Pa≈øture, Turbary, Pi≈øcarie, &c.

Appendant are Ho≈øpitalls,Appendant. Patronages of Churches and Benefices (Valuable not in contriuing commodities by Church-Chaffering, but equiualent in validitie
by rea≈øon of the priuiledge of electing or pre≈øenting a worthy Clarke, (who mu≈øt be Idoneus) to ≈øucc√©ede and ≈øupply the vacancie of the Church) Al≈øo Common of Fi≈øhing, of E≈øtouers, of Vicinage.

Dormant.Dormant Perqui≈øites are ≈øuch things as are euer pre≈øt and ready at the in≈øtant commaund and plea≈øure of the Lord; as Villaines & Neifes, which are alwayes ≈øaide to be Regardant to a Manour.Regardant. And to this place may al≈øo be indifferently referred Salt Naturall, Sande, Grauell, Marle, Earth and ≈øuch other thinges as are alwaies di≈øpo≈øeable by the Po≈ø≈øident for deriuing an immediate profit or Reuenewe.

p.hi: So much for Perqui≈øites: Parallels en≈øue.

div.head: CAP. III.
div.p: Parallels.BY Parallels I intend all pur≈øuites of wilde Game, which for moderate exerci≈øe of the body and delight full refection of the minde, are held in priuate e≈øt√©eme of Pur≈øuite, or in valueable validity of the Purcha≈øe of the Pray, equiualent to profitable Accrewments. And they are either Generous, as Hunting and Hawlking: Or Plebeious, as Fi≈øhing and Fowling.

It is therefore not impertiment to the purpo≈øe to intimate what ≈øeuerall Games are v≈øually found within the Precincts and Priuiledges of the Plot or F√©e, and how the Countrie is accommodated for Chace, View, Flight, &c.

Hunting.For Hunting, Record what Bea≈øts of the Forre≈øt there be, and how frequent: as the Hart, the Hinde, the Hare, the Boare, the Woolfe: Of the Chace, Buckes, Does, Foxes, Martrones, Roes: In like manner what Beauers, Badgers, Otters, Wilde-Cats.

Hawlking.Fir≈øt for Hawlking: Fowles of Warren, as Fe≈øant
and Partridge: then the Elke, bu≈øtard, Heron, Mallard, Ducke, Teale, Heath-Cocke, Rayle, Rock-doue, Pie, Black-bird, Thru≈øh.
Fi≈øhing is either in Fre≈øh-waters; as for Samon,Fi≈øhing. Trout, Carpe, Pike, Manat, Breame, Barbell, Tench, Perch, Cheuin, Dace, Roach, Ruffin, Eeles, Lampreys Gudgeon, Minnowes, Crea-fi≈øh.

Or in Seas and other Salt-waters, for the Sturgion, Turbot, Porpuis, Seale, Bret, Tunie, Holibut, Mullet, Rochet, Gurnets, Gilt-heade, Ba≈øe, Dorce, Macheril, Whiteing, Hering, Haddock, Thornbacke, Codfi≈øh, K√©eling, Hake, Dog-fi≈øh, Horne-fi≈øh, Conger, Lamp≈øon, Bowman, Soles, Playce, Buts: the Lob≈øtar, Crabbe, Pearle-fi≈øh, Prawne, Sea and Wood Tortei≈øe Oy≈øters, Conchyles, Winkles, Purples, Cutle, Callough, Cockles, Mu≈økles, Shrimps. Al≈øo for the Sea-Pike, Carpe, Troute, Breame, Tench.

Fowling may be for the Bittour, Curlewe, Mallard,Fowling. Pyntayl, Stockard, Duck, Teal, Snipe, Shouelar, Stork Cormorant, Gaunt, Sheldrake, Cob, Oliue, Puffin, Pewet, Yarwhelpe, Red≈øhank, Ruffe or Reue: the Godwit, Gnat-≈ønap, Knot: Gray, Gr√©ene and Ba≈øtard Plouer, Quaile, Dottrill, May-Chit, Spawe, Churre, P√©eper, Grindle, Skirwingle, Sea and Land Larkes: The Crane, Storke, Cocke of the Wood, Wood-Cocke, Heath-Cocke, Heath-Poote, Grou≈øe, Turtill; with which the Cuckow, and Owle, may for their delicatie b√©e rancked: then the E≈øtridge, Birdes of Paradi≈øe, Canary Birdes, Parrots, &c.
Likewi≈øe for Hawlkes: as the Falcon, Ierfalcon, Tercel-gentle, Lanar, Lanaret, Leto, Ierkin, Saker, Sakret, Marline, Hobby. And ≈øhort winged Hawlkes: as the Go≈ø≈øe-Hawlke, and Spare-Hawlke.

p.hi: And this may ≈øuffize for Reuenewes: It Re≈øts now to intreat of Repri≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: Repri≈øes.REpri≈øes are impo≈øitions and duties whereunto the Plot or F√©e is in peculiar lyable; and they are Reall and Per≈øonall.

Reall.Reall Repri≈øes are al Charges and payments impo≈øed, whether by Cu≈øtome or by Couenant, for maintenance or repaire of Bridges, Sea-banckes, Hauens, Sluces, Ietties, Wharfes, Goates, Cau≈øeyes, Waies, &c.
And in this Rancke may be Mar≈øhalled al Re≈øolutes Decha≈øhes, Decrements.

Per≈øonall.Per≈øonall Repri≈øes are Seruices, Duties, and Payments by Tenure to the Lord or Lordes Me≈øn or Paramount: as Fealty, Homage, E≈øcuage, &c. Court-≈øuite, Out-Rents, Boonage, Fines, Heriots, Reliefes, Re≈øpight of Homage, &c. Or by Graunt or D√©ed to Couenant√©es; as Rent-Charge, Extents, Pentions, Portions, F√©es, Corrodies, Salaries, Stipends, Dowres, Annuities, &c. to Diuines, Arti≈øts, Lingui≈øts, Lawyers, Patent√©es, Feoff√©es, Seruitors, Officers, &c.

p.hi: Valuation Reiterant is thus decyphered:
The Determinant remaines.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: Determinant Valuation.DEterminant Valuation concludes and determines the Right and Intere≈øt of the Po≈ø≈øident by Alienation of the F√©e or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

And in this Action, ≈øith it is not Reiterable, it is expedient to retriue the vtmo≈øt Value and worth; to
which purpo≈øe that due prizalls may be produced, e≈øtimate all particulars both in Reuenew vt ≈øupra: And al≈øo Re≈øpectiue; as Edifices, Heire-Loomes, Engines, Timber, Tin≈øel, Ward-≈øhips, Aduow≈øions, Villaines, Commons, Wa≈øts, and other things in Gro≈ø≈øe, with all Perqui≈øites of like Nature.
Now by oppo≈øing the E≈øtimation of Repri≈øes to the Totall Valuation, the Remanet is rectified, and the true Value retriued.
And thus much for the fir≈øt part of a Compleate Suruey.

div.head: Briefe directions for orderly mar≈øhalling of Surueyes, for accommodating of Field-entries in Rough-Bookes, for Engro≈ø≈øements and their Exemplifications with framing of Terrars, Rentals, Cu≈øtome and Court-Rolls, Particulars, &c.
div.p: FOr other In≈øtructions and Pre≈øidents requi≈øite for methodical operations in Surueying of Lands & Euidences, with formal Exemplifications incident therevnto, I mu≈øt deferre them till the impre≈ø≈øion of the Second part.

In the meane time, not altogether to defraud the expectation of the diligent, I haue intimated the≈øe fewe Inductions en≈øuing, which though they may ≈ø√©eme too cur≈øorie and incompetent, to giue full ≈øati≈ø-faction and information for the due di≈øpo≈øures of the copious remarkables, occurrent in a compleat Suruey, in fit Symboliographie; yet I doubt not but the ingenious Practizer may pick-forth more ample Pre≈øidents, than may ≈ø√©eme (at fir≈øt viewe) to be comprizable in the decurted Pa≈ø≈øages, as well of the former Tractate, as of this Supplement.

To Suruey a Manour: Out of the Series and Prota≈øis
formerly dilated, contriue the Articles (≈øuiting the exigence of the Seignorie) to be giuen in charge to the Iurie, and that in writing for more ≈øub≈øtantiall and direct proc√©eding.

The Tenants, both Feudataries and Termors, entred, the Charge ended, and their E≈øtates ≈øummarily recorded, your A≈ø≈øi≈øtants ready, and all things prepared, proc√©ede to the Suruey, de≈øcribing Plots and noting in a Rough-booke (in Folio) all occurrents as they fall remarkable.
And in this practi≈øe you are not coÃÑfined to imitate or in≈øi≈øt vpon the precedent Prota≈øis or other Pre≈øident, nor abridged of a voluntary propo≈øition of any other iudicious Method.

The alternate Pages may bee delineated into certaine generall and Collaterall Heads for expedition, as well of the entries in≈øtant, as of engro≈ø≈øements to be ≈øelected, noting all Extrauagants orderly in the appropriate parallel of the oppo≈øite Page; ≈øo ≈øhall you auoide diffu≈øed accumulations, which would confound and puzzle the ≈øpeciall Head in mar≈øhalling forth particular and due contriuances.

Nor ≈øhall it be impertinent to Kalander or Characterize each Modulet of the Ploat with the rough Entrance, thereby to facilize and expedite the ingro≈ø≈øements incident, in contriuing whereof an indige≈øted Chaos of ob≈øeruations, would much intricate you, in regard the order pur≈øued in perambulation, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be inuerted in the Exemplification.

div.head: Page 2. oppo≈øite.
div.p: This Pa≈øture is proiected in large Ridges extended and declining South; the Soile is a ≈øandy Clay of 18 inches Cru≈øt clo≈øe ≈øworded and well repleate with Trefoiles, Cinquefoile, Ribwort, Mor≈øus, Yarrow, and other gra≈øing Herbes of good growth, with a Dayrie Hou≈øe in the N. W. corner of two good Bayes, and a faire Pond 7 pole direct Ea≈øt from the Hou≈øe, ≈øpringing from the We≈øt forth of a male grauell the Ba≈øe of the Soile: the Hedge-Rowes are well growne and ≈øtored with Peare-tr√©es and Appletr√©es of good Fruite, &c.
1. In the≈øe entries the Tenant is both expre≈ø≈øed and a≈ø≈øigned his Modulet with the Character.
2. There are opponed Re≈øidence, Species, Habitude, Cra≈ø≈øitude, Inue≈øture, Ground-Plots, Edifices (Engines) tho la≈øt 3 mu≈øt al≈øo be plotted.
Now to Engro≈ø≈øe a compleate Suruey:Engro≈ø≈øement. Modulize Alternate Pages, and particulate the Oppo≈øite with due ob≈øeruations, and characterize the Euidences.
To exemplifie the Engro≈ø≈øement without delineation of the Models, there is a method to be pur≈øued in the particular Entries (according to their Eminences and kindes) of E≈øtates and Euidences.
In Fr√©e-holds Record the Po≈ø≈øident, Title, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions,Free-hold. Tenure, De≈øcent and Re≈øeruation.
In Copy-holds; the Po≈ø≈øident, Title, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions,Copie-hold. Habendum, Fine, Re≈øeruation.
In Lea≈øes; Commencement, Parties, Demi≈øe,Demi≈øe. Habendum, Reddendo, Couenants.
In ≈øpirituall liuings; Site, Edifices, Glebe, Decimals,Rectorie. vicarage. Repri≈øes, Valuation, E≈øtimate, Patronage, Incumbent.
Medowe, Pa≈øture, Arable, require ≈øeueral Contents.
In the Entries of all ≈øaue the fir≈øt, the Boundage & Extent of Cartelages mu≈øt-be-recorded.
In Edifices and Engines their dimen≈øions, matter, forme, and Repaire are remarkable.
Out of the Exemplification of the whole Compo≈øition and Body of the Suruey, the≈øe ≈øub≈øequents may be ≈øelected (viz. Terrars, Rentals, Cu≈øtomaries, Suit-Rolls, and Particulars) and thus framed.
Terrars.Dige≈øt in orderly compo≈øure, Edifices, Home≈øteads, Curtelages, lands, ground-plots, &c. with their qualities, ≈øites, and proportions.
Rentalls.Compo≈øe in computable dige≈øtment all the Tenants with their Tenements and Rents in particular.
Cu≈øtomaries. Suit-Rolls.Recorde in fit contriuance all and ≈øingular the Cu≈øtomes and Priuiledges of the Manour.
Inroll all the Feudataries & Suiters to the Court with their F√©es, Tenurage, Rents, and Seruices.

Particulars.Particularize Qualities, Contents, Rents (in≈øtant and improueable) Perqui≈øites, Parallels and other Reuenewables and Re≈øpectiues, with vendible and di≈øtinct E≈øtimates; Reduce all Repri≈øes to a due Method and Record the Remanet.
Sequences.And for retriuing validities of e≈øtates, it is not impertinent to deriue the Sequences in D√©eds from Aunce≈øtrie, and thereby to contriue Offices for the Tenure.Offices.

Non-parcel.For other the Lords Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions compri≈øed in the Suruey, and reputed no part or member of the Manour, they require to be recorded apart in the Infra, vnder the Title of Non-Parcels: Vizt, Churches, Chappels, Almes-hou≈øes, &c. Al≈øo Patronages, Villaines, Commons, Annuities, and other particulars helde in Gro≈ø≈øe.
